Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Saturday! [KONTROL] w/ 3 Channels (Poland) LIVE+DJ sets, and Alland Byallo's LIVE debut!

------=_Part_17868_26600333.1186184302870
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=WINDOWS-1252
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

Saturday, August 4th, 2007

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


featuring from Poland:

3 CHANNELS  :  LIVE set + DJ sets

( Crostown Rebels . Trapez . Trenton . Resopal . Dirtybird )

Deeop and Ketiov started off as DJs intent on exposing Poland to the new
sounds of techno and house, which quickly led them to hosting club events
and a weekly radio show. In the last few years they've blown up as
producers, dropping sought-after releases and remixes on hot labels like
Crosstown Rebels, Trapez, Trenton, and SF's own Dirtybird.  Now they're
taking their in-demand talent to the final frontier, touring North America
and perfoming together LIVE for the first time.


and a world premiere performance by [KONTROL]'s own:

ALLAND BYALLO  :  LIVE!!!

( Leibe*Detail . Floppy Funk )

Between his roles as graphic designer, webmaster, radio host, DJ, and
producer/remixer, Alland Byallo is a man on a techno mission. This month,
riding high on a slew of ace productions, he too takes it up a notch with
the world premiere of his all original LIVE performance.


plus special guest:

NIKITA  ( The Endup . djnikita.com )

Nikita regularly rocks The Endup alongside Nikola Baytala Sunday mornings
after Kontrol is "technically" over.  Those who stay after the bar re-opens
though know the party keeps rocking until noon, making for monthly 14-hour
techno marathons. Tonight we're pleased to give you "night people" a taste
of what you've been missing.


and [KONTROL] residents:

NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( Robsoul . Junior Boys Own . S.W.A.T. )
CRAIG KUNA   ( Concept SF . ESDJCO )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( Leibe*Detail . Floppy Funk )
SAMMY D  ( Classic . Buzzin' Fly . Dirtybird )

________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

____________________________________________________


Full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

[ground.KONTROL] on Western Addition Radio:
http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/

Flyer front:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K26/K26F.jpg
Flyer back:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K26/K26B.jpg
Poster:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K26/K26P.jpg

____________________________________________________


3 CHANNELS

3 Channels are Deeop (Grzegorz Demianczuk) and Ketiov (Wojciech Taranczuk).
Their acquaintance began in 2003 when Ketiov started to spin his first
records in clubs like Sonar and Taras Caffe and Deeop was already widely
known for his enormous record collection and participation in every party i=
n
the city of Stettin.  In late 2003 they organized their first mutual party
at Mezzoforte club, which was a huge success. Logically they became residen=
t
DJ's there, which gave them a chance to organize their own parties simply
named "Electronic House". The idea was to promote new dance music completel=
y
different from what was played in most of the Polish clubs at the time. The
"Electronic House" parties had the privilege to welcome such people as Tom
Clark, Dub Taylor, John Tejada, Antonelli Electr, Wighnomy Brothers, Todd
Bodine, Matthias Tanzmann and Duplex 100.

In September 2003 they broadcasted their first radio show called "Session"
at the local ABC Radio alongside with their old mate Vitek. After a year
"Session" evolved into the 3 Channels project. Later the radio show was
broadcast under the name of "Plastelina" and could be heard every Thursday
from 6pm to 7pm. "Plastelina" has no sound limits one simple goal, which is
to promote modern electronic music from downtempo to house, tech-house and
techno.

After half a year of co-operation with Votchik, 3 channels decided to start
producing.  They released their 2 first records on Trenton ("Split EP" and
"Superficial") followed by 1 EP each on Trapez and Crosstown Rebels, which
showed a more minimal side of their work.  All these releases showed that 3
Channels could be versatile artists and collected a lot of good reviews all
over the world in media sources like the BBC and Anja Schneider's popular
radio show "Dance Under The Blue Moon".  They are now starting to do remixe=
s
for people such as Jacek Sienkiewicz, Maetrik, Richard Bartz, Codec'n Flexo=
r
and are releasing new productions on labels like Trenton, Crosstown Rebels,
Trapez and Resopal.  3 Channels have recently started to play live and have
launched their own label called Channels. They have also begun producing
under an alias, "Catz n Dogz" with an upcoming release on SF's own Dirtybir=
d
Records.


3 Channels' Website:
http://www.3channels.pl

3 Channels on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/3channels

3 Channels' Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/3%20channels

3 Channels 2006 Promo DJ Mix:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K26/3_channels_-_september_2006_promo_mix.mp3


________________________________________________


ALLAND BYALLO

A Los Angeles native now residing in San Francisco, Russian-blooded Alland
Byallo has broken into the electronic music scene with his own unique blend
of Minimal Tech funk. Alland's taste, coupled with his research and digging=
,
always instills an undeniable groove and tickles the chin-scratching
trainspotting senses.

Alland's involvement with music didn't just start from splurging and buying
some 1200's. Having been raised with music since the age of 5 playing piano=
,
and adding trumpet at age 11, it only seemed natural for Alland to follow u=
p
his skills and training by sharing his taste in quality music with people a=
s
a DJ, and pursuing production. Lately, Alland has been quite busy in the
studio working hard on his own unique take on electronic dance music,
blending the ethics of minimal techno with the moods and feel of house
music.

Alland has hosted the infamous netradio show Comfort Sessions for four
years, only recenlty switching to an On-Demand format with Proton Radio, th=
e
most respected netradio portal in Underground Electronic music. The show is
inspired by a couple of things: The admiration and respect for some of the
most talented names out there, and the love of enlightening and educating
others about music and the brilliant artists who make it all happen. Alland
has made it his mission to give back to the local and global scene that has
given so much to him; to make the world aware of the missions of those
around him that truly deserve recognition and respect.

Currently, A&R for his own digital label, Nightlight Music and his upcoming
label Kvadrat Produkt, takes up much of Alland's time. Nightlight Music
started as a digital label used as an outlet for Alland's personal music
projects. But since it's inception, the label has grown to accomodate some
of the world's most talented and passionate tech-house artists. Kvadrat
Produkt is a new label that Alland is creating to fill a certain void.
"Minimal Yet Musical" is the motto for this venture. As the name implies
(Kvadrat meaning "square" in many languages), the vehicle is minimalism, ye=
t
filled with mass that supports the structure.

After releasing a slew of successful and well-received tracks over the last
two years on respected European labels such as Leibe*Detail, Floppy Funk,
and Shva Musik, Alland has recently devoted his time to putting together a
live set that will surely be making its way across America and the rest of
the world soon.  [KONTROL] is extremely proud to present the world premiere
of Alland's live performance on his home court at SF's legendary Endup.


Alland's Website:
http://www.allandbyallo.com/music.html

Alland on MySpace:
http://www.mypsace.com/alland

Alland's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Alland%20Byallo

DJ Set recorded live @ [KONTROL] July 07:
http://www.allandbyallo.com/interface/Alland%20Byallo%20@%20[KONTROL]%20Jul=
y%207%202007%20.mp3

_____________________________________________________


NIKITA

It wasn't too long ago that Nikita ventured out from Denver, Colorado to
California to pursue his dreams of working in the music industry.  Nikita's
music career began in San Francisco promoting the long-running 177 Club
Townsend a.k.a. Club Universe and attending SFSU where he studied Audio
Engineering and Music Business. In the past six years Nikita's perseverance
and pure love for quality dance music has placed him among the top DJs of
San Francisco's world-famous club scene.

In 2005 Nikita was chosen to host his own radio show on Northern
California's Energy 92.7 FM =96 The Massive Mix. Recognizing his popularity
with the local crowds and his cutting edge DJ style, executives at
California's only FM dance station knew what most clubbers have already com=
e
to realize: if you want a fresh, cutting edge dance party with the hippest
crowd, look no further than Nikita. It was Nikita's raw talent that landed
him a residency at San Francisco's legendary nightclub, The EndUp, as well
as his recently acquired bi-weekly residency at the internationally
acclaimed Supperclub.

Whether it's 2 or 8 hours, Nikita's sets at The EndUp take you on a ride
seamlessly blending deep melodic grooves, techno, breaks, and twisted
tribal-tech house, yet still keeping it soulful and deep, bending all genre=
s
and creating a unique dance floor experience that continues to draw a
diverse audience. Currently Nikita is working on his own music productions,
so be sure to look out for his releases hitting speakers sometime soon!

For the last several months Nikita has played the post-Kontrol opening
Sunday morning sets at the Endup alongside fellow Endup resident Nikola
Baytala, effectively stretching the event into a monthly 14 hour techno
marathon. No longer content with sharing his talent with only the morning
crowd, we are pleased to present this local hero to the [KONTROL] faithful
with a proper peak hour set.


Nikita's Website:
http://www.djnikita.com

Nikita on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/djnikita

_____________________________________________________

http://www.kontrolsf.com

sound system.  But they're not really made to be driven while playing...

R/S used as an album cover for one of his early releases:
http://www.discogs.com/image/R-108524-1122354681.jpg

shit in my car, and keep the good stuff at home (your dollar goes a lot 
further on home systems and headphones than car audio).  It's not like 
cars have the best acoustics/background noise specs anyway.

Hello raver friends!

I have a room for rent in my wonderful loft space in Alameda.  Yes, it's in
Alameda, it's really not as distant and isolated at it sounds...  We live in
a little creative haven complete with colorful walls, large bass bins,
awesome neighbors/building-mates, a pinball arcade, and a lovely beach a
short walk away.  See here for more info:
http://sfbay.craigslist.org/eby/roo/391148663.html

Love Chelsea Faith

------=_Part_109175_11340914.1186525271435--

Subject: [sfraves] [bsp] LoveFest techno fundraiser w/ 3 CHANNELS tonight @ 222!

Howdy folks!

First off, thanks to everyone that made it out to Kontrol on Saturday
night. Alland really appreciated all the support and positive feedback
on his debut live set, and oh man... were 3 Channels ever great!  A
very special thanks to our wonderful guests Gregory and Voitek from
Poland/Berlin for turnin' the place out into the wee hours.

Secondly, we've got some big news, just announced!  Since 3 Channels
will be here in SF for a couple more days, we invited them to come
down to play the new monthly Auralism party called "Lil Brthr" which
happens first Tuesdays at the 222 club. THEY SAID YES!  So, you get a
surprise chance to hear them one more time before they leave (or a
first time if you missed them Saturday.)  Saturday was their second
gig EVER in the US, by the way, and who knows when these guys might be
back!

So, yes it's true... Poland's 3 CHANNELS are DJing tonight at 222 Hyde
in SF, probably from around 12pm - 2am.

This event is also going to be a fundraiser for a Kontrol/Auralism
float at this year's LoveFest! So, if you want to hear some great
techno / minimal / tech-house at this year's festival, please come
down and support with a donation of a Lincoln or a Hamilton (or hell,
a Benjamin if you're so inclined!) :)

The full lineup is here:
http://a915.ac-images.myspacecdn.com/images01/124/l_6f52c04b53fa2dbaf748a22a38cca372.jpg

This is going to be sweet, these guys seriously killed it Saturday
night! Don't miss this rare opportunity to see this amazing duo in
such an intimate location. Hope to see you tonight!


-----> Greg, Alland, Craig, Sammy & Nikola


p.s. Oh wait, one more thing!  Our friend James Bass and his
Bassaholics Anonymous crew are throwing an underground party this
Saturday night featuring badass Detroit legend DJ BONE on 3 decks!
[KONTROL] resident Craig Kuna will be warming things up for him from
1-2am (playing a harder techno set this time), and yours truly will be
serving up libations behind the bar!  Come get saucy with us and jack
to some classic bangin' Detroit bizness.  Full info here:
http://www.bassaholicsanonymous.com/

Thanks for supporting techno in SF!

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

Here's a little factoid I did not know and pulled it off the Wikipedia
page for George Mason, one of our founding fathers and who George
Mason University is named after.

Paris Hilton is a direct descendant of George Mason. Mason's tenth son
Thomas Mason was Paris Hilton's
great-great-great-great-great-great-great grandfather.

The article goes on to reference that George Mason is the one who
wrote the predecessor to the Bill of Rights in the Constitution, and
refused to sign the Constitution because it did not have those
provisions.

--

We came equals into this world, and equals shall we go out of it. All
men are by nature born equally free and independent. To protect the
weaker from the injuries and insults of the stronger were societies
first formed; ? Every society, all government, and every kind of civil
compact therefore, is or ought to be, calculated for the general good
and safety of the community. Every power, every authority vested in
particular men is, or ought to be, ultimately directed to this sole
end; and whenever any power or authority whatever extends further, or
is of longer duration than is in its nature necessary for these
purposes, it may be called government, but it is in fact oppression.

- George Mason

Indeed it will not-

And quoting single sentences out of context is the tool of... a tool.

Paul, writing in his independent political newsletter in 1992, reported  
about unspecified surveys of blacks."Opinion polls consistently show that  
only about 5 percent of blacks have sensible political opinions, i.e.  
support the free market, individual liberty and the end of welfare and  
affirmative action,"Paul wrote.Paul continued that politically sensible  
blacks are outnumbered "as decent people." Citing reports that 85 percent  
of all black men in the District of Columbia are arrested, Paul  
wrote:"Given the inefficiencies of what D.C. laughingly calls the  
`criminal justice system,' I think we can safely assume that 95 percent of  
the black males in that city are semi-criminal or entirely criminal," Paul  
said.Paul also wrote that although "we are constantly told that it is evil  
to be afraid of black men, it is hardly irrational. Black men commit  
murders, rapes, robberies, muggings and burglaries all out of proportion  
to their numbers."

------=_Part_5044_13531539.1186592454079
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

It's not racist to say, "85% of black men in this city have been arrested,
and they probably missed a few" or "Black men commit the large majority of
all violent crimes despite blacks being a 13% minority in this country."

That's called stating facts, supported by police and court statistics.

It's also not racist to vote against the federal government spending money
in ways it's not authorized, unless you can find me a white person whose
Congressional Gold Medal Ron Paul voted for.  Seems he just doesn't think
the government has the authority to spend money in that way (which it
doesn't, not constitutionally at least).


On 8/8/07, Nyc W. Alberts <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> I dunno, Sport, seems to me like the almighty hallowed "context" you
> speak of more or less gets the same racist points Paul's making there
> across.
>
> As does Paul's votes in Congress on Emmit Till and Rosa Parks.
>
> Or am I missing something?
>
> You don't trainwreck much on the decks when you  grace the world with
> your DJ'ing skills, do you?
>
> .
>
> Nathan Seven wrote:
> >
> >
> > And quoting single sentences out of context is the tool of... a tool.
> >
> > Paul, writing in his independent political newsletter in 1992,
> > reported about unspecified surveys of blacks."Opinion polls
> > consistently show that only about 5 percent of blacks have sensible
> > political opinions, i.e. support the free market, individual liberty
> > and the end of welfare and affirmative action,"Paul wrote.Paul
> > continued that politically sensible blacks are outnumbered "as decent
> > people." Citing reports that 85 percent of all black men in the
> > District of Columbia are arrested, Paul wrote:"Given the
> > inefficiencies of what D.C. laughingly calls the `criminal justice
> > system,' I think we can safely assume that 95 percent of the black
> > males in that city are semi-criminal or entirely criminal," Paul
> > said.Paul also wrote that although "we are constantly told that it is
> > evil to be afraid of black men, it is hardly irrational. Black men
> > commit murders, rapes, robberies, muggings and burglaries all out of
> > proportion to their numbers."
> >

No, I'd say it's pretty fucking racist to say those things. In fact, you are
a racist for defending them. What would not be racist to say is that people
of color are disproportionately targeted for arrest and harassment by pretty
much every police department in the country, almost as a matter of policy.

You shouldn't be trying to talk about how many black men commit crimes, you
should be asking yourself, and the country at large, why so many black men
feel compelled to commit those crimes.

The answer is not 'because they're criminals.' If you can't see past the
statistics into the truth of the situation you really have no business
trying to spread your bigotry and hatred of a people that did nothing to
you.

How come the best cocaine in town is the powder in Atherton, but when I 
pick up the paper all I ever see is people in East Palo Alto getting 
arrested for buying rock?

If it's not about opportunity, and denied opportunity, pretend you're a 
parent.

Where would you want your kid to go to school?

OJ Simpson's HS in the projects of Potrero Hill, or Barry Bonds's HS in 
San Mateo?

Not voting to give Rosa Parks a Congressional Medal is flat out retarded 
beyond measure.

Having her body  Lie In State at the U.S. Capitol Rotunda in Washington 
DC for her funeral probably wasn't "Constitutional" either but it was 
the right thing to do, as was voting for the Emmit Till Unsolved Crimes Act.

Anytime you want to come join the plur of the 21st Century, we'll be 
glad to have you, but please check your hate at the door.

Thanks!!!

victim-mentalities have children who become just like them-
This is how you end up with 3 fucking generations of people living in the  
same house in the same project-

them- because they don't want to change.
This is why fuckers will be wearing $100 pants and brand new shoes, and be  
asking me for 50 cents.
And people like you who keep telling them they are victims and it's not  
their fault just reinforce the idea more.
The community needs to clean *itself* up- and I really hope it does before  
the checks stop flowing- otherwise you're going to see Superdome-II...

No thanks- I'll remain in the real world :)

First of all, statistics aren't facts. They're statistics. The statistics in
and of themselves aren't racist, but the way you're using them is incredibly
so.

You're obviously white, so let me ask you, why do you feel so threatened by
black people? What is it that all the supposedly raping, murdering black
people have done to you? Do you really think that the color of someone's
skin can determine whether or not they're going to be a
thief/rapist/murderer/whatthefuckever it is you're scared of this week?

Let's be honest about what you're trying to say here. Don't fucking bullshit
me. You think black people are criminals simply because they're black.
That's what you're trying to say, so own up to it. Now think about that.
Really fucking think about it. Is it rational? Does it make sense? At all?
Or are you just a scurred little white boy who's been trained by the media
to be afraid of his own (black) shadow?

Finally, you're a lot closer to the truth in your final line than you know.
I can fix it for you, here:

"I think the answer is the fact that we keep subsidizing the rich with
corporate welfare."

MUCH better.

If that crackhead had a house to live in I'm sure he'd be smoking his rock
there. Most likely he doesn't, so he smokes it on the street. Now, if the
government provided him with one, and maybe some meaningful assistance to
get his life together, maybe he wouldn't have to wander the streets trying
to get high all the time.

There is nothing wrong with people taking care of each other. ALL people
need to take care of ALL other people. You say 'the community has to clean
*itself* up,' so tell me, what are you doing to clean up the community? I
bet you like to think of yourself as separate from the crackheads and the
homeless, and well, basically anyone with skin tone darker than fluorescent
lights, but I've got a news flash for you: You're not. You are part of the
same race as those people. There's a part of you in them and vice versa. If
you really care so much about the 'community' what are you doing to help
clean it up?

After all, you said the community needs to clean itself up, and you are in
fact a part of the community. So what the fuck are you doing to help?

Hmm?

> victim-mentalities have children who become just like them-

thugs that will shoot you *after* they've robbed you just so theur friends  
know they're a REAL G.  Doesn't matter what color they are to me at all.

> Do you really think that the color of someone's
> skin can determine whether or not they're going to be a
> thief/rapist/murderer/whatthefuckever it is you're scared of this week?

Of course not- dress, movement, body language and facial expression are  
much more telling of someone's intention.
The security procedures used by El Al (the Israeli airline) are about the  
best examples of effective profiling you can find today.

> Let's be honest about what you're trying to say here. Don't fucking  
> bullshit
> me. You think black people are criminals simply because they're black.
> That's what you're trying to say, so own up to it. Now think about that.
> Really fucking think about it. Is it rational? Does it make sense? At  
> all?
> Or are you just a scurred little white boy who's been trained by the  
> media
> to be afraid of his own (black) shadow?

about this?
The media works the exact opposite of how you seem to see it-
You get something like the Duke rape case- a horrific white on black  
gang-rape- and it's nationwide news.
Black on white gang-rape?  Happens all the time but barely makes the local  
paper.
Hmm what's this?
La Shawn Barber seems to agree with me here- and OMG SHE'S BLACK?!?!
http://lashawnbarber.com/archives/2007/07/25/jaded-journalists-spice-up-black-on-white-rape-story/

That's a nice sentiment and all, but let's go back to what you, quoting Ron
Paul, said originally:

Paul, writing in his independent political newsletter in 1992, reported
about unspecified surveys of blacks."Opinion polls consistently show that
only about 5 percent of blacks have sensible political opinions, i.e.
support the free market, individual liberty and the end of welfare and
affirmative action,"Paul wrote.Paul continued that politically sensible
blacks are outnumbered "as decent people." Citing reports that 85 percent
of all black men in the District of Columbia are arrested, Paul
wrote:"Given the inefficiencies of what D.C. laughingly calls the
`criminal justice system,' I think we can safely assume that 95 percent of
the black males in that city are semi-criminal or entirely criminal," Paul
said.Paul also wrote that although "we are constantly told that it is evil
to be afraid of black men, it is hardly irrational. Black men commit
murders, rapes, robberies, muggings and burglaries all out of proportion
to their numbers."

Maybe I'm blind, but I don't see a lot of shit about body language and the
kind of clothes someone's wearing in there. I do see a lot of mention of
something else, though. . .

Can't say I've heard of La Shawn Barber, but if she's disseminating the view
that black men gang raping white women is happening *all* the time she's
probably not too well informed. Rape is an awful crime, no matter who
commits it. It's interesting that you mention the Duke Rape Case, since
those white rapists that you mentioned were acquitted. Ironically, that's
EXACTLY the shit I'm talking about. Had the races been reversed, not only
would we have not heard about it in the news, but every single one of the
accused would be rotting away in prison right now. No questions asked.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Yeah, big props to Pinkko for putting words in my mouth and developing
clairvoyance, because there's no other way to arrive at his
conclusions about me from my actual words.

If you're so keen on asking why things happen, how about asking why the
crackhead doesn't have a house?  I'd guess it's because you don't like the
answer: nobody bought one for him. He's spent his whole life expecting
someone else to provide his lifestyle for him and doing crack, instead of
WORKING for his living (gasp!).  Nathan nailed it, the root of the problem
is the victim-mentality and entitlement culture surrounding all this
seemingly-perpetual poverty.  I've watched people break free from it with
absolutely no advantages over their neighbors and become successful, rich
even, without committing a single crime.  It may be harder for a black child
living in poverty to become successful than a middle class white child, but
it happens more often than many care to admit, and it leaves little excuse
for those who don't.

As for your personal insults to me, it's an easy way for you to avoid
discussing my points.  Conjecturing that someone you don't know is racist
and does nothing to contribute to the community has nothing to do with the
discussion at hand.

What matters to me is someone's behavior.  If someone, regardless of skin
color, creeps up behind me on the street at night, dressed like a thug, I'm
going to be scared.  If someone, regardless of skin color, spends their life
focusing on leeching off of the good will of others instead of taking
advantage of education and getting a job, then I don't think the system that
permits that behavior is a good one and I don't think their attitudes are
commendable.  It's truly sad that a disproportionate number of people from
some races fall into these categories, but they themselves, not their
circumstances, finances, culture, or race, are responsible for their own
choices and behaviors, and I hold them accountable the same way I hold
everyone accountable.

Concerning Rosa Parks and the Congressional Medal: what Rosa Parks did was
undeniably good and worthy of praise, recognition, and honor, and I doubt
that Ron Paul or anyone else here feels any differently.  However, whether
or not the government should spend $30,000 of taxpayer money giving her, OR
ANYONE ELSE, a medal is a completely different question.  Sure, $30k is
peanuts compared to the rest of the budget, but the point is that Ron Paul
votes consistently according to a constitutional view of government and
letting $30k slide because it's a small amount for an emotionally charged
and good-publicity-getting cause unfortunately wouldn't be consistent, now
would it?

I'll end with a quote:
> Anytime you want to come join the plur of the 21st Century, we'll be
> glad to have you, but please check your hate at the door.

No thanks- I'll remain in the real world :)

>that
>permits that behavior is a good one and I don't think their attitudes are
>commendable.  It's truly sad that a disproportionate number of people from
>some races fall into these categories, but they themselves, not their
>circumstances, finances, culture, or race, are responsible for their own
>choices and behaviors, and I hold them accountable the same way I hold
>everyone accountable.
>
>Concerning Rosa Parks and the Congressional Medal: what Rosa Parks did was
>undeniably good and worthy of praise, recognition, and honor, and I doubt
>that Ron Paul or anyone else here feels any differently.  However, whether
>or not the government should spend $30,000 of taxpayer money giving her, OR
>ANYONE ELSE, a medal is a completely different question.  Sure, $30k is
>peanuts compared to the rest of the budget, but the point is that Ron Paul
>votes consistently according to a constitutional view of government and
>letting $30k slide because it's a small amount for an emotionally charged
>and good-publicity-getting cause unfortunately wouldn't be consistent, now
>would it?
>
>I'll end with a quote:
> > Anytime you want to come join the plur of the 21st Century, we'll be
> > glad to have you, but please check your hate at the door.
>
>No thanks- I'll remain in the real world :)
>
>
>

Personal insults? Calling someone that says racist shit a racist isn't a
personal insult, that's just calling a spade a spade.

Your lack of understanding of this world is fueled no doubt by Fox News and
Bill O'Reilly. Try being homeless for a while. Try starving for a while. Try
not being able to find a job or pay rent or do any of the things you take
for granted every single fucking day of your life.

It's easy for an educated white man to say that the disadvantaged just
haven't taken advantage of all the wonderful education and work
opportunities that are given to them. Have you ever even seen what a school
in the ghetto looks like? You know that kids in the poorer schools here
learn history with books that STILL SAY USSR in them? How the FUCK are you
going to look at the way things work now and tell me it's a level playing
field? That the problems we see in the streets are personal, not systemic?

Your entire line of reasoning is: "Poor people are poor, so they should have
to work harder than I do, because I'm not poor and, well fuck them for being
poor in the first place." No. FUCK YOU for helping to create a system that
is so unjust and allows so few to take so much while leaving so many with so
little.

GODDAMN you suck at being a human being.

On 8/8/07, Matthew Johnson <prayformojo524@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Yeah, big props to Pinkko for putting words in my mouth and developing
> clairvoyance, because there's no other way to arrive at his
> conclusions about me from my actual words.
>
> If you're so keen on asking why things happen, how about asking why the
> crackhead doesn't have a house?  I'd guess it's because you don't like the
> answer: nobody bought one for him. He's spent his whole life expecting
> someone else to provide his lifestyle for him and doing crack, instead of
> WORKING for his living (gasp!).  Nathan nailed it, the root of the problem
> is the victim-mentality and entitlement culture surrounding all this
> seemingly-perpetual poverty.  I've watched people break free from it with
> absolutely no advantages over their neighbors and become successful, rich
> even, without committing a single crime.  It may be harder for a black child
> living in poverty to become successful than a middle class white child, but
> it happens more often than many care to admit, and it leaves little excuse
> for those who don't.
>
> As for your personal insults to me, it's an easy way for you to avoid
> discussing my points.  Conjecturing that someone you don't know is racist
> and does nothing to contribute to the community has nothing to do with the
> discussion at hand.
>
> What matters to me is someone's behavior.  If someone, regardless of skin
> color, creeps up behind me on the street at night, dressed like a thug, I'm
> going to be scared.  If someone, regardless of skin color, spends their life
> focusing on leeching off of the good will of others instead of taking
> advantage of education and getting a job, then I don't think the system that
> permits that behavior is a good one and I don't think their attitudes are
> commendable.  It's truly sad that a disproportionate number of people from
> some races fall into these categories, but they themselves, not their
> circumstances, finances, culture, or race, are responsible for their own
> choices and behaviors, and I hold them accountable the same way I hold
> everyone accountable.
>
> Concerning Rosa Parks and the Congressional Medal: what Rosa Parks did was
> undeniably good and worthy of praise, recognition, and honor, and I doubt
> that Ron Paul or anyone else here feels any differently.  However, whether
> or not the government should spend $30,000 of taxpayer money giving her, OR
> ANYONE ELSE, a medal is a completely different question.  Sure, $30k is
> peanuts compared to the rest of the budget, but the point is that Ron Paul
> votes consistently according to a constitutional view of government and
> letting $30k slide because it's a small amount for an emotionally charged
> and good-publicity-getting cause unfortunately wouldn't be consistent, now
> would it?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

On Wed, 08 Aug 2007 12:48:21 -0700, pinkko <ealaughlin@gmail.com> wrote:

> After all, you said the community needs to clean itself up, and you are  
> in fact a part of the community. So what the fuck are you doing to help?

Pinkko- there are two concepts I'm going to introduce you to-

1) tough love - the whole "give a man a fish/teach a man to fish" thing:
Maybe you've got a younger brother who kinda lived in your shadow, and  
instead of having to buy his own car and get a job and pay rent etc, he  
was just given a brand new car and was allowed to live at home rent-free.
Maybe you're old enough now to see that the reason he's almost 30 and  
still living at home with no job and only about $1000 in assests is  
specifically because of all the help he was given- it bred complacency and  
a reliance on the support system instead of self-sufficiency.
Maybe you actually feel really bad because you helped him out a lot before  
you saw the kind of cycle it created- and wish you hadn't...
The black community doesn't need its hand held, it needs its ass kicked-  
just like my brother-

2) self-identity:

> Maybe I'm blind, but I don't see a lot of shit about body language and  
> the
> kind of clothes someone's wearing in there. I do see a lot of mention of
> something else, though. . .

Right- you see "black!" and "race!" and your eyes fill with fire- know why?
Maybe you have a friend who, whenever he loses something- he thinks it's  
been stolen.
Why does he think that?  It's because he's a theif himself- his mind works  
in a thieving manner, so instead of a balanced response- "huh i dunno what  
happened to it"- he always thinks it's been stolen.

So when I read something like this:

> "Opinion polls consistently show that
> only about 5 percent of blacks have sensible political opinions, i.e.
> support the free market, individual liberty and the end of welfare and
> affirmative action,"

I think: "Hmmm only 5%?  Why is this segment of the community so  
ill-informed about such things?  Someone's dropping the ball somewhere..."

But when you read it- your head goes in to RACIST! mode-
Maybe you've figured out where I'm going with this :)
Err- I guess I'm already there- but the fact that you respond in such a  
manner tells me more about your true inner nature than you probably  
realize...

-- 
NUNQUAM NON PARATUS - Jupiter accepts your offer...
AIM: IMFDUP

You're so full of shit that I'm not even going to bother responding to your
points. You clearly have no idea what you're talking about, so all I'm going
to do is ask you a question:

How much time have you spent talking to homeless people? Like, listening to
their stories?

I'm willing to bet it's a bit less than I have. These are human beings we're
talking about, not fucking cattle. You don't help someone out of the gutter
by putting your boot on their neck. Do you even see how the wealth that you
have is taken directly from these people? You should read some Marx,
asshole, you could learn a lot from him.

Finally, I don't see 'black' and immediately think 'RACISM.' I see shit like
this:

Citing reports that 85 percent
of all black men in the District of Columbia are arrested, Paul
wrote:"Given the inefficiencies of what D.C. laughingly calls the
`criminal justice system,' I think we can safely assume that 95 percent of
the black males in that city are semi-criminal or entirely criminal," Paul
said.

And think 'holy shit, that's fucking racist as fuck.' Why? BECAUSE IT IS.

If you're going to be saying this racist shit, you should at least own up to
the fact that you're being fucking racist.

> instead of having to buy his own car and get a job and pay rent etc, he
> was just given a brand new car and was allowed to live at home rent-free.
> Maybe you're old enough now to see that the reason he's almost 30 and
> still living at home with no job and only about $1000 in assests is
> specifically because of all the help he was given- it bred complacency and
> a reliance on the support system instead of self-sufficiency.
> Maybe you actually feel really bad because you helped him out a lot before

> been stolen.
> Why does he think that?  It's because he's a theif himself- his mind works

Yeah, Champ, you're right again.

Single mother goes on welfare and uses the time to write a series of 
books that create the largest single personal fortune in the UK, you're 
right, bad example

I'll be sure to check my head that next time I engage my keyboard.

Actually dude puts it better than I can here:

> Chances are that you have heard of J. K. Rowling. Even if you have 
> not, you have heard of her work. J. K. Rowling is the author of the 
> _Harry Potter_ books. Her story is fascinating.
>
> At the time she was writing the first Harry Potter book, Rowling was a 
> single mother. In a /Publishers Weekly/ article published on December 
> 21, 1998, there are two important pieces of information about Rowling:
>
>       "Lacking child care and unable to take a job without it, she
>       [Rowling] went on public assistance. In many ways, she says, it
>       was one of the lowest points of her life." 
>
> And:
>
>       "She found Christopher Little in 1995, in the /Writers' &
>       Artists' Yearbook/ (the UK equivalent of /Literary Market
>       Place/). He was the second agent to see her book -- the first
>       had sent it back "virtually by return of post," with a form
>       letter. In the year that followed, three publishers declined the
>       book on the grounds that it was too long for children." 
>
> Obviously Rowling's original book, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's 
> Stone <http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/059035342X>, was a good 
> book. It sold millions of copies. Her fourth book, Harry Potter and 
> the Goblet of Fire 
> <http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0439139600> had a first 
> press run of 3.8 million copies -- the largest first press run in 
> history. Over 30 million copies of the series have been sold.
>
> When you think about it, it is a miracle that any of us ever got to 
> read Harry Potter. Consider the fact that a book with this much 
> potential was written by a person on welfare. Think about how many 
> other works -- music, art, literature, engineering, science, invention 
> -- have never seen the light of day because of the same sorts of 
> social problems (or because the potential author/artist/inventor is 
> working 12 hours a day scrubbing toilets in two minimum wage jobs to 
> make ends meet). Think about the arrogance of the first three 
> publishers who rejected the manuscript. Think about how many valuable 
> works have never seen the light of day because of that same arrogance. 
> Society as it is designed today wastes an unbelievable amount of human 
> potential through mechanisms just like these.
>
> At the very least, Rowling's story shows us that the economic theory 
> underpinning our world contains an element of dysfunction. It should 
> not be the case that highly creative people sitting on top of billion 
> dollar ideas have to go on welfare (and reach "one of the lowest 
> points" in their lives by doing so) in order to express themselves. By 
> removing this dysfunction, we could discover millions of Rowlings.
>
Nathan Seven wrote:
> On Wed, 08 Aug 2007 11:57:32 -0700, Nyc W. Alberts 
> <digitalcomponents@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>> Good thing we made that no account, free-loader, that immoral, unwed,

>

I'd also like to point out that you actually don't know my race or
background, because I haven't told you.  There are plenty of well-educated
blacks who say the same things that I do, so it would be equally valid to
assume that I'm one of them, wouldn't it?

You similarly know absolutely nothing about what I've done to help other
people less fortunate than I.  You have no idea what I've read (FYI I've
read plenty of Marx, more than enough to realize that his ideas are
terrible), or what news sources I use (ps: not Fox).  You had no idea that
both my parents are teachers and that yes, I've seen plenty of the shitty
side of the education system (and if you think it's bad in California you
should see some of the schools in Louisiana).  You might want to stop making
up things about me before you lose all shred of credibility.

Now let's look at a few things you've done in this conversation.  You've
quoted Ron Paul out of context about 4 different times.  You've ignored
other people's points instead of addressing them when you disagreed.  You've
provided no solid reasoning or demonstrative proof for your views, and your
only defense against other people's reasoning is to accuse them of racism
(without any support for your view).  You've resorted to rampant swearing in
a debate.

Is it too much to ask for you to leave the conversation gracefully, before
you insult more people who don't deserve it and lose even more face?  Or if
you'd like to discuss instead of rant, be my guest.

It's not racist to talk about behaviors, attitudes, and criminal
statistics.  That's all we're doing, and if you'd stop being so convinced
that any idea other than yours is racist you might be able to see that.  I
would never deny that we can do better (note: better doesn't necessarily
mean "more") at providing opportunities for the less privileged in this
country, but I hold people accountable for their choices nonetheless.


On 8/8/07, pinkko <ealaughlin@gmail.com> wrote:

> on
> slavery.

On Wed, 08 Aug 2007 13:34:15 -0700, pinkko <ealaughlin@gmail.com> wrote:

> You clearly have no idea what you're talking about, so all I'm going to  
> do is ask you a question:

Clearly... I'm pretty much done with this conversation, but you did ask me  
a direct question-

> How much time have you spent talking to homeless people? Like, listening  
> to
> their stories?
>
> I'm willing to bet it's a bit less than I have.

The extent of my "speaking" to the homeless has generally been me telling  
them what worthless pieces of shit they are while I was kicking them-
Though I guess it was more spit than words coming out :P

Ya you might not want to take that bet- I'm a think-globally, act-locally  
kind of guy-
The list is pretty long so I'll just give you some highlights-
I'm on a first name basis with most of the non-tweaker locals and know why  
they are where they are-
I've let some live in my house, when the shelter was full-
I've let some stay in my vehicles in my yard- a couch in a van is a pretty  
pimp pad when you're homeless and it's raining.
I've given a couple nice new boots and a warm jacket for xmas-
I've paid them to do work in my yard and on my house-
I drove one to court so he wouldn't miss his date and go back to jail-
I counseled another one of them at length about how ridiculous it was for  
him, at age 60, to be working his ass off living in his van with his dog,  
but sending all his money to his apartment-dwelling good-for-nothing  
jobless god-daughter and her also-jobless bf/pimp/dealer.
Oh he also was sending money to a Nigerian scammer for a cell phone so he  
could retrieve his share of Dr. Uembbe Ooblasanj's secret lost oil  
fortune... so I handled that too.

> Finally, I don't see 'black' and immediately think 'RACISM.' I see shit  
> like
> this:
>
> Citing reports that 85 percent
> of all black men in the District of Columbia are arrested, Paul
> wrote:"Given the inefficiencies of what D.C. laughingly calls the
> `criminal justice system,' I think we can safely assume that 95 percent  
> of
> the black males in that city are semi-criminal or entirely criminal,"  
> Paul
> said.
>
> And think 'holy shit, that's fucking racist as fuck.' Why? BECAUSE IT IS.

You're just proving my point- a balanced reading of that would be "85% of  
all black males here have been arrested?  And that's just the criminals  
that have been caught?  That's a big problem- no wonder the community is  
in shambles- what could be causing this?"

> > What matters to me is someone's behavior.  If someone, regardless of skin

> > focusing on leeching off of the good will of others instead of taking
> > advantage of education and getting a job, then I don't think the system that

> > circumstances, finances, culture, or race, are responsible for their own

1.  It is racist to assume that the justice system missed out on 10 % 
of criminals, solely because they are black.

2.  It is, in fact, just as likely that 75% of the black men in the 
city are criminals, and the 10% error goes the other way.

3.  Criminals are people that are tried and convicted.  Just because 
someone's been arrested, a criminal he does not make.  If 85% of the 
black men in DC have been arrested, it could be due entirely to 
racial profiling by the police.

I was going to berate each of you 3 for your terrible logic, but it's 
so not worth my time. :)

crime are also under-represented by the same amount-

undetected/unreported- there's no color line there.

> 2.  It is, in fact, just as likely that 75% of the black men in the city  
> are criminals, and the 10% error goes the other way.

and I'm fairly certain it far outweighs any contribution caused by corrupt  
police and fabricated crimes and planted evidence etc-

> 3.  Criminals are people that are tried and convicted.  Just because  
> someone's been arrested, a criminal he does not make.  If 85% of the  
> black men in DC have been arrested, it could be due entirely to racial  
> profiling by the police.

"arrested" versus "convicted"?
If so- I entirely concede that profiling could be the cause of that- but I  
also would argue that profiling is in fact a most effective way of  
deterring crime- whether you like to admit it or not.
See my El Al mention a couple posts back-

Subject: [sfraves] Beatport DJ?  Program to rename your songs

--0-378600814-1186629924=:24733
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hola,

I wrote a small program to rewrite the filenames of songs you download from beatport.com to include the Track, Artist, and Label.  Thank you Forest Green and Andy Highland for the ideas.

They currently only include the Beatport song ID and Track name, making it very easy to forget who actually wrote the songs.

It's written in Python, and instructions on how to use it and where to get it are here:

http://phillip.freedomring.net

Feel free to modify it at your own will and for your own purposes. :)

-Phillip




--0-378600814-1186629924=:24733--

My only idea is that it's easier to control all the artists if no one knows who they are...

It is definitely intentional, as the song names are written based on entries in the database.

This was the first revision, I'll see if I can make it more user friendly with maybe a little GUI later on.



Gavin Varitech <gavin@djvaritech.net> wrote: Love the idea, but it's too complicated for me. Why doesn't Beatport 
just put it where it should be?

Phillip Mispagel wrote:
> Hola,
>
> I wrote a small program to rewrite the filenames of songs you download from beatport.com to include the Track, Artist, and Label.  Thank you Forest Green and Andy Highland for the ideas.
>
> They currently only include the Beatport song ID and Track name, making it very easy to forget who actually wrote the songs.
>
> It's written in Python, and instructions on how to use it and where to get it are here:
>
> http://phillip.freedomring.net
>
> Feel free to modify it at your own will and for your own purposes. :)
>
> -Phillip

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beatport DJ?  Program to rename your songs

On Wed, Aug 08, 2007 at 08:25:24PM -0700, Phillip Mispagel wrote:
>Hola,
>
>I wrote a small program to rewrite the filenames of songs you download from beatport.com to include the Track, Artist, and Label.  Thank you Forest Green and Andy Highland for the ideas.

The beatport track naming is annoying.

>They currently only include the Beatport song ID and Track name, making it very easy to forget who actually wrote the songs.
>
>It's written in Python, and instructions on how to use it and where to get it are here:
>
>http://phillip.freedomring.net

I had the same frustration, so I created a multi-step process that
includes a proxy (paros), perl scripts (XML::Twig and DBD::SQLite)
that tag and rename after converting wav to flac, and a couple
shell one-liners.

I need to clean it up, but I suppose if someone was interested I'd share
some/all of it. You need to be rather technical to use it in its current
state.

-- 
Holt Sorenson
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com
myspace.com/hsomusic

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Thu)

Here, why don't you guys argue over this for a while.

SFRaves is dead.

--

By its own admission, 84 of every 100 children screened by TeenScreen
are falsely identified as having a "mental disorder." That?s 84%
falsely identified, falsely labeled. When identified as having a
mental disorder, students are referred to a mental health
professional. More times than not, students are then placed on
prescription anti-depressants; medications that carry a FDA black-box
warning that they can cause violent behavior and/or suicide. An
increasing number of school-shooters have been on anti-depressants,
including Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold (Columbine; Jefferson County,
Colorado) and Kip Kinkel (Springfield, Oregon).

- Lynn Stuter, Newswithviews.com, "The Second Amendment and Mental Disorders"

http://www.newswithviews.com/Stuter/stuter103.htm

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Actually, I'm trying to buy as many cuts a week as I can, sometimes I get
pretty close to 100. I don't let the beatport filenames get me down, though.
They properly fill out all their id3 tags, so (on Vista at least), you can
in the OS get the track name, artist, and sometimes even record label. I use
Serato, which has excellent support for ID3 tags, so I don't really have
that problem. I'd recommend finding something to play with that understands
ID3, it makes your life a lot easier, no shell scripts necessary.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beatport DJ? Program to rename your songs

On Thu, Aug 09, 2007 at 09:46:06AM -0700, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
>No one ever heard of creating a simple notepad document and just jotting 
>down track names/artists then renaming the files?

That would take too long.

>You ain't buying 100 damn tracks a week I am sure...

Buying thirty tracks once makes automation worth it.

>It's amazing how much work folks will go through to be lazy, lol.

Three desirable attributes of programmers, according to Larry Wall
are: laziness, impatience, and hubris. For more on this browse
to:

http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/opensources/book/larry.html

Here's one track I have, properly named:
(threshold_productions)_never_forever_[rpo_remix].flac

Its original name was something like:
150294_Never_Forever_RPO_Remix.wav

Its tag is as follows:
METADATA block #2
  type: 4 (VORBIS_COMMENT)
  is last: false
  length: 281
  vendor string: reference libFLAC 1.1.2 20050205
  comments: 8
    comment[0]: ORGANIZATION=Frekency Records
    comment[1]: DATE=2006-06-29
    comment[2]: ARTIST=Threshold Productions
    comment[3]: COMMENT=Label: Frekency Records
    comment[4]: TITLE=Never Forever [RPO Remix]
    comment[5]: GENRE=Progressive House
    comment[6]: DESCRIPTION=Label: Frekency Records
    comment[7]: VERSION=RPO Remix

Its database entry is:
456|150294|Never Forever|RPO Remix|08:00|1|2006-06-13|2006-06-29|$1.49|Frekency Records|Progressive House|Progressive House|Threshold Productions|Never Forever|Buy|General Content|Rick Pier O'Neil|8297164|http://www.beatport.com/user/downloads/download/?downloadId=8297164|wav|Beatport

I have no interest in typing all that in by hand for one song, the
commands to convert it from wav to flac by hand, or the commands to
tag, enter it into the db, etc by hand.

I *do* have to make entries into the db by hand for vinyl and CD, but
after that, the rest of the work is done with the automation I have.

-- 
Holt Sorenson
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com
myspace.com/hsomusic


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> >From: Holt Sorenson
> >To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> >Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beatport DJ? Program to rename your songs
> >Date: Thu, 9 Aug 2007 18:27:58 +0000
> >
> >On Thu, Aug 09, 2007 at 09:46:06AM -0700, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
> > >No one ever heard of creating a simple notepad document and just
> jotting
> > >down track names/artists then renaming the files?
> >
> >That would take too long.
> >
> > >You ain't buying 100 damn tracks a week I am sure...
> >
> >Buying thirty tracks once makes automation worth it.
> >
> > >It's amazing how much work folks will go through to be lazy, lol.
> >
> >Three desirable attributes of programmers, according to Larry Wall
> >are: laziness, impatience, and hubris. For more on this browse
> >to:
> >
> >http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/opensources/book/larry.html
> >
> >Here's one track I have, properly named:
> >(threshold_productions)_never_forever_[rpo_remix].flac
> >
> >Its original name was something like:
> >150294_Never_Forever_RPO_Remix.wav
> >
> >Its tag is as follows:
> >METADATA block #2
> >   type: 4 (VORBIS_COMMENT)
> >   is last: false
> >   length: 281
> >   vendor string: reference libFLAC 1.1.2 20050205
> >   comments: 8
> >     comment[0]: ORGANIZATION=3DFrekency Records
> >     comment[1]: DATE=3D2006-06-29
> >     comment[2]: ARTIST=3DThreshold Productions
> >     comment[3]: COMMENT=3DLabel: Frekency Records
> >     comment[4]: TITLE=3DNever Forever [RPO Remix]
> >     comment[5]: GENRE=3DProgressive House
> >     comment[6]: DESCRIPTION=3DLabel: Frekency Records
> >     comment[7]: VERSION=3DRPO Remix
> >
> >Its database entry is:
> >456|150294|Never Forever|RPO
> >Remix|08:00|1|2006-06-13|2006-06-29|$1.49|Frekency Records|Progressive
> >House|Progressive House|Threshold Productions|Never Forever|Buy|General
> >Content|Rick Pier
>
> >O'Neil|8297164|http://www.beatport.com/user/downloads/download/?download=
Id=3D8297164|wav|Beatport
> >
> >I have no interest in typing all that in by hand for one song, the
> >commands to convert it from wav to flac by hand, or the commands to
> >tag, enter it into the db, etc by hand.
> >
> >I *do* have to make entries into the db by hand for vinyl and CD, but
> >after that, the rest of the work is done with the automation I have.
> >
> >--

> >     comment[0]: ORGANIZATION=Frekency Records
> >     comment[1]: DATE=2006-06-29
> >     comment[2]: ARTIST=Threshold Productions
> >     comment[3]: COMMENT=Label: Frekency Records
> >     comment[4]: TITLE=Never Forever [RPO Remix]
> >     comment[5]: GENRE=Progressive House
> >     comment[6]: DESCRIPTION=Label: Frekency Records
> >     comment[7]: VERSION=RPO Remix
> >
> >Its database entry is:
> >456|150294|Never Forever|RPO
> >Remix|08:00|1|2006-06-13|2006-06-29|$1.49|Frekency Records|Progressive
> >House|Progressive House|Threshold Productions|Never Forever|Buy|General
> >Content|Rick Pier
> >O'Neil|8297164|http://www.beatport.com/user/downloads/download/?downloadId=8297164|wav|Beatport
> >
> >I have no interest in typing all that in by hand for one song, the
> >commands to convert it from wav to flac by hand, or the commands to
> >tag, enter it into the db, etc by hand.
> >
> >I *do* have to make entries into the db by hand for vinyl and CD, but
> >after that, the rest of the work is done with the automation I have.
> >
> >--
> >Holt Sorenson
> >hso@hsomusic.com
> >hsomusic.com
> >myspace.com/hsomusic

the bus is special like that.

working is one thing - u have a place to go. 

when ur homeless and trying sell a lil bit of herb to get a place to stay for the night and a crew of high school fat asses from fillmore take ur shit b/c ur white it's fucked up. B/c u know they are going home to mommy and daddys that night and counting their bill wads and laughing. 

But if they want to battle, i'll show them who the hardest emcee is any day of the week - i;ll say bring it - b.c i don;t have shit to lose and even if i did i'll just get double what i lost after a few months.

the old timers know the game - and ignorance is the #1 cause of rascism.

u don't see attitudes - u get fucked over when ur down.

u should have seen my bruises after i got jumped in hunter's point - i know i shouldn't of gone there - but i was new to the city and sleeping on busses got off for a cig and boom. I didn't have a dollar on me - all they got was my back pack which had my journal in it (all my flows) and my passport. Both things that were far more valuable to me then anyone else. Why should a part of the city be sectioned off. This is Frisco, not LA.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beatport DJ? Program to rename your songs

On Thu, Aug 09, 2007 at 12:34:36PM -0700, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
>Control + F isn't cutting it?

nope. neither does WinKey + F, Option + F, or any of the following:

ls -latR |grep -i foo
find . -type f -name \*foo\*
find . -type f -name \*.flac -print0 |xargs -0i@ metaflac --list --block-type VORBIS_COMMENT @ |grep -i foo

however, 'select * from trackz where artist like "%foo%";' works rather
nicely.

It's clear from our conversation that our requirements for track
finding and selection differ--and that is fine.

:)

Holt Sorenson

myspace.com/hsomusic

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

There's a "lack of balance on the streets" cuz folks of the darker variety 
have been shoved into the streets much moreso than little crackers...

But I grew up in the dirty District (DC), aka Chocolate City, and I have 
spent mad time in the seedier parts there, Baltimore, Oakland, Denver, and 
to a lesser extent SF - and as long as you don't carry yourself like a 
victim, 9 times out of ten you won't be one. Not saying there aren't 
exceptions to that rule - but you need to be aware of your surroundings, and 
if you are in the 'hood, you need to watch your ass.

I hate to say it, but I have little sympathy for folks who put themselves in 
harm's way and then wonder why bad shit happens to them. It still sucks if 
it happens, but c'mon - don't go wandering around the 'hood if you don't 
want to get rolled.

> > > > > > > getting

> > > > > > > you're

>From: Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com>

>On Thu, Aug 09, 2007 at 12:34:36PM -0700, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
> >Control + F isn't cutting it?
>
>nope. neither does WinKey + F, Option + F, or any of the following:
>
>ls -latR |grep -i foo
>find . -type f -name \*foo\*
>find . -type f -name \*.flac -print0 |xargs -0i@ metaflac --list 
>--block-type VORBIS_COMMENT @ |grep -i foo
>
>however, 'select * from trackz where artist like "%foo%";' works rather
>nicely.
>
>It's clear from our conversation that our requirements for track
>finding and selection differ--and that is fine.
>
>:)

i agree with entirely

Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote: There's a "lack of balance on the streets" cuz folks of the darker variety 
have been shoved into the streets much moreso than little crackers...

But I grew up in the dirty District (DC), aka Chocolate City, and I have 
spent mad time in the seedier parts there, Baltimore, Oakland, Denver, and 
to a lesser extent SF - and as long as you don't carry yourself like a 
victim, 9 times out of ten you won't be one. Not saying there aren't 
exceptions to that rule - but you need to be aware of your surroundings, and 
if you are in the 'hood, you need to watch your ass.

I hate to say it, but I have little sympathy for folks who put themselves in 
harm's way and then wonder why bad shit happens to them. It still sucks if 
it happens, but c'mon - don't go wandering around the 'hood if you don't 
want to get rolled.

> > >did
> > > > was

> > > > whether

> > > > her, OR
> > > > > > ANYONE ELSE, a medal is a completely
> > different question.  Sure, $30k
> > > > is
> > > > > > peanuts compared to the rest of the budget,

> > >Ron
> > > > Paul
> > > > > > votes consistently according to a
> > constitutional view of government
> > > > and
> > > > > > letting $30k slide because it's a small
> > amount for an emotionally
> > > > charged
> > > > > > and good-publicity-getting cause

> > >consistent,
> > > > now
> > > > > > would it?

Morgan McCloud <mogopolis2000@yahoo.com> wrote: i agree with entirely

Van Mundegaarde  wrote: There's a "lack of balance on the streets" cuz folks of the darker variety 
have been shoved into the streets much moreso than little crackers...

But I grew up in the dirty District (DC), aka Chocolate City, and I have 
spent mad time in the seedier parts there, Baltimore, Oakland, Denver, and 
to a lesser extent SF - and as long as you don't carry yourself like a 
victim, 9 times out of ten you won't be one. Not saying there aren't 
exceptions to that rule - but you need to be aware of your surroundings, and 
if you are in the 'hood, you need to watch your ass.

I hate to say it, but I have little sympathy for folks who put themselves in 
harm's way and then wonder why bad shit happens to them. It still sucks if 
it happens, but c'mon - don't go wandering around the 'hood if you don't 
want to get rolled.

> > > > > > peanuts compared to the rest of the budget,

Morgan McCloud  wrote: i agree with entirely

Van Mundegaarde  wrote: There's a "lack of balance on the streets" cuz folks of the darker variety 
have been shoved into the streets much moreso than little crackers...

But I grew up in the dirty District (DC), aka Chocolate City, and I have 
spent mad time in the seedier parts there, Baltimore, Oakland, Denver, and 
to a lesser extent SF - and as long as you don't carry yourself like a 
victim, 9 times out of ten you won't be one. Not saying there aren't 
exceptions to that rule - but you need to be aware of your surroundings, and 
if you are in the 'hood, you need to watch your ass.

I hate to say it, but I have little sympathy for folks who put themselves in 
harm's way and then wonder why bad shit happens to them. It still sucks if 
it happens, but c'mon - don't go wandering around the 'hood if you don't 
want to get rolled.

> > > > > > > and does nothing to contribute to the
> > > community has nothing to do
> > > >with
> > > > > the
> > > > > > > discussion at hand.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > What matters to me is someone's behavior.
> > > If someone, regardless of
> > > > > skin
> > > > > > > color, creeps up behind me on the street at
> > > night, dressed like a
> > > > > thug, I'm
> > > > > > > going to be scared.  If someone, regardless
> > > of skin color, spends
> > > > > their life
> > > > > > > focusing on leeching off of the good will of
> > > others instead of
> > > >taking
> > > > > > > advantage of education and getting a job,
> > > then I don't think the
> > > > > system that
> > > > > > > permits that behavior is a good one and I
> > > don't think their
> > > >attitudes
> > > > > are
> > > > > > > commendable.  It's truly sad that a
> > > disproportionate number of
> > > >people
> > > > > from
> > > > > > > some races fall into these categories, but
> > > they themselves, not
> > > >their
> > > > > > > circumstances, finances, culture, or race,
> > > are responsible for their
> > > > > own
> > > > > > > choices and behaviors, and I hold them
> > > accountable the same way I
> > > >hold
> > > > > > > everyone accountable.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Concerning Rosa Parks and the Congressional
> > > Medal: what Rosa Parks
> > > >did
> > > > > was
> > > > > > > undeniably good and worthy of praise,
> > > recognition, and honor, and I
> > > > > doubt
> > > > > > > that Ron Paul or anyone else here feels any

> > > > > whether
> > > > > > > or not the government should spend $30,000

> > > > > her, OR
> > > > > > > ANYONE ELSE, a medal is a completely
> > > different question.  Sure, $30k
> > > > > is
> > > > > > > peanuts compared to the rest of the budget,

> > > >Ron
> > > > > Paul
> > > > > > > votes consistently according to a

From sfraves-return-140610-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Aug 09 21:37:37 2007
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-140610-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 63170 invoked by uid 1103); 9 Aug 2007 21:37:36 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 63154 invoked from network); 9 Aug 2007 21:37:35 -0000
From: tsheets@saturn5.com
Date: Thu, 9 Aug 2007 14:37:33 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20070809213732.GA2495@atari.saturn5.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
User-Agent: Mutt/1.5.13 (2006-08-11)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Ahhh, burningman.


Burning Man Art.

Its cool and all, it really is.  But man.. is it really worth bankrupting
yourself and devoting untold time to suspend 2 big rigs in the air?  I mean,
yeah, it looks cool and all.  But... man! the scale!  I know you have
to be a little crazy to want to do art, but to budget it, get BM money,
then ask the community for another $20,000... I mean.. there is probalby 
a lot of other cool art this guy could have done for a more modest budget.

I mean, he needs 3 flatbed trucks to get it to the playa?

Okay, I am posting this poking fun at the poor guy, but who knows, maybe
some sfraves are sympathetic to his cause?  Personally, would rather donate
money to a battered woman's shelter then this over-wrought peice of BM art.
But maybe that is just me....

-------------------------------

SPECIAL ART EDITION

Two of our most ambitious honorarium projects for 2007 are BigRigJig by
Mike Ross and JIm Mason's  Mechabolic: Cyborg Speculations in Machine
Metabolism.

Although Burning Man funded both projects, each has exhausted their
budget and is in need of financial support. We have never before
approached the community for help like this, but we are  unable to
further fund these projects, so we are calling on our readers for help
in a few ways.

Mike Ross of Big Rig Jig - (see the project at http://www.bigrigjig.com
- it's literally awesome) - reports:

"Things are going well on the project.  We are on schedule, and ramping
things up dramatically for the last few weeks.  Several new core crew
members just arrived from New York with a burst of energy and
enthusiasm.  We are working full time, 7 days a week, from about 2pm to
4am (last two nights till 5am, actually).  Its an amazing group of
people that can sacrifice months of their lives, working that hard to
pull something like this off.  Im lucky to have them around.  And we are
all lucky to have Burning Man provide the opportunity for us.

Unfortunately, despite our best and continued efforts, we are out of
money.  Putting two big rig trucks 40 feet up in the air is enormously
difficult, especially when you come from out of town (we moved our
entire operation from Brooklyn, NY to California in order to build this
sculpture).  We received the majority of our funding from the Burning
Man grant, and immediately began seeking additional sources to make up
for the remainder of our budget.  But between setting up a new shop,
finding our materials in an unfamiliar environment, and actually
building the project, our time is stretched thin.   The long and short
of it is that we have so far failed to find the additional funding we
need.  As of two weeks ago,  the project is being funded by personal
credit cards, which is difficult as I have no source of income right
now, and have already spent my savings on the project.  If you know of
any emergency funding opportunities, or other helpful people or
resources, we would be much obliged. You can help with in kind donations
of materials, too.

If you can help, please contact   mikenon@gmail.com
Donate via PayPal to: donate@bigrigjig.com

Funding Needs:
To meet costs, we need to raise approximately $20,000.  Any donation,
large or small, helps.

Some specific in kind donations would help reduce this. Wish List:

   * I-beams: 72 feet of W14x109 I-beam (or approximate equivalent)
   * Road Plates: 5 road plates (or approximate equivalent) borrowed or
purchased
   * Chrome Truck Accessories, such as: air filter assemblies, exterior
"chicken" lights, bumpers, exhaust "stacks", rims
   * Lighting: exterior par cans or other lights which can project onto
the surface of the sculpture
   * 20 kW generator, or approximate equivalent, for use during 2-week
pre-event installation
   * Transportation Services: 3 full-length flatbeds from Oakland to the
playa before the event, and from playa to Oakland afterwards

Also, we can always use more volunteers in Oakland of various skill
levels, from skilled metal fabricators/welders, to anyone willing to
spend a few hours holding a grinder.





-- 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
tsheets@saturn5.com                                  <- You have found me   
http://www.ferrapsylix.com                           <- sub atomic breakbeat
"I just don't have the discipline to be a hippie"    <- Homer J. Simpson

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>From: tsheets@saturn5.com
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] Ahhh, burningman.
>Date: Thu, 9 Aug 2007 14:37:33 -0700
>
>
>Burning Man Art.
>
>Its cool and all, it really is.  But man.. is it really worth bankrupting
>yourself and devoting untold time to suspend 2 big rigs in the air?  I 
>mean,
>yeah, it looks cool and all.  But... man! the scale!  I know you have
>to be a little crazy to want to do art, but to budget it, get BM money,
>then ask the community for another $20,000... I mean.. there is probalby
>a lot of other cool art this guy could have done for a more modest budget.
>
>I mean, he needs 3 flatbed trucks to get it to the playa?
>
>Okay, I am posting this poking fun at the poor guy, but who knows, maybe
>some sfraves are sympathetic to his cause?  Personally, would rather donate
>money to a battered woman's shelter then this over-wrought peice of BM art.
>But maybe that is just me....
>
>-------------------------------
>
>SPECIAL ART EDITION
>
>Two of our most ambitious honorarium projects for 2007 are BigRigJig by
>Mike Ross and JIm Mason's  Mechabolic: Cyborg Speculations in Machine
>Metabolism.
>
>Although Burning Man funded both projects, each has exhausted their
>budget and is in need of financial support. We have never before
>approached the community for help like this, but we are  unable to
>further fund these projects, so we are calling on our readers for help
>in a few ways.
>
>Mike Ross of Big Rig Jig - (see the project at http://www.bigrigjig.com
>- it's literally awesome) - reports:
>
>"Things are going well on the project.  We are on schedule, and ramping
>things up dramatically for the last few weeks.  Several new core crew
>members just arrived from New York with a burst of energy and
>enthusiasm.  We are working full time, 7 days a week, from about 2pm to
>4am (last two nights till 5am, actually).  Its an amazing group of
>people that can sacrifice months of their lives, working that hard to
>pull something like this off.  Im lucky to have them around.  And we are
>all lucky to have Burning Man provide the opportunity for us.
>
>Unfortunately, despite our best and continued efforts, we are out of
>money.  Putting two big rig trucks 40 feet up in the air is enormously
>difficult, especially when you come from out of town (we moved our
>entire operation from Brooklyn, NY to California in order to build this
>sculpture).  We received the majority of our funding from the Burning
>Man grant, and immediately began seeking additional sources to make up
>for the remainder of our budget.  But between setting up a new shop,
>finding our materials in an unfamiliar environment, and actually
>building the project, our time is stretched thin.   The long and short
>of it is that we have so far failed to find the additional funding we
>need.  As of two weeks ago,  the project is being funded by personal
>credit cards, which is difficult as I have no source of income right
>now, and have already spent my savings on the project.  If you know of
>any emergency funding opportunities, or other helpful people or
>resources, we would be much obliged. You can help with in kind donations
>of materials, too.
>
>If you can help, please contact   mikenon@gmail.com
>Donate via PayPal to: donate@bigrigjig.com
>
>Funding Needs:
>To meet costs, we need to raise approximately $20,000.  Any donation,
>large or small, helps.
>
>Some specific in kind donations would help reduce this. Wish List:
>
>    * I-beams: 72 feet of W14x109 I-beam (or approximate equivalent)
>    * Road Plates: 5 road plates (or approximate equivalent) borrowed or
>purchased
>    * Chrome Truck Accessories, such as: air filter assemblies, exterior
>"chicken" lights, bumpers, exhaust "stacks", rims
>    * Lighting: exterior par cans or other lights which can project onto
>the surface of the sculpture
>    * 20 kW generator, or approximate equivalent, for use during 2-week
>pre-event installation
>    * Transportation Services: 3 full-length flatbeds from Oakland to the
>playa before the event, and from playa to Oakland afterwards
>
>Also, we can always use more volunteers in Oakland of various skill
>levels, from skilled metal fabricators/welders, to anyone willing to
>spend a few hours holding a grinder.
>
>
>
>
>

the point was, compression at all when you start out as wav...just, why?
you're burning it to a CD anyway, and HDD storage is beyond cheap these
days.  Staying as wav is called "sound quality"

and FLAC is terrible, maybe it's LESS lossy (it's not truly lossless, just
thought I'd mention) than other formats but it's pretty terrible in most
other ways.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beatport DJ? Program to rename your songs

FLAC is lossless. After it's decompressed, you end up with a bitwise 
identical copy to the original input (WAV) file.


On Thu, 9 Aug 2007, Matthew Johnson wrote:

> also, you lose a generation of quality regardless, I'm sure I don't need to

> converting

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beatport DJ? Program to rename your songs

On Thu, Aug 09, 2007 at 04:57:14PM -0500, Matthew Johnson wrote:
>the point was, compression at all when you start out as wav...just,
>why?
>you're burning it to a CD anyway,

For those that burn to CD, this applies.

>and HDD storage is beyond cheap these days.

sure, but why waste it if you can save space by 1/3? CPU time is even
cheaper than storage these days.

$ ls -ahl 93020_Foxy_Moron_Original_Mix.wav
-rw-r--r-- 1 hso users 63M 2007-07-27 08:18
93020_Foxy_Moron_Original_Mix.wav

$ ls -lah breaks/\(soul_of_man\)_foxy_moron_\[original_mix\].flac
-rwxr--r-- 1 hso users 38M 2007-07-27 22:39
breaks/(soul_of_man)_foxy_moron_[original_mix].flac

>Staying as wav is called "sound quality"

>and FLAC is terrible, maybe it's LESS lossy (it's not truly lossless,
>just
>thought I'd mention) than other formats but it's pretty terrible in
>most
>other ways.

Not sure what you mean here.  You need to supply data to back up your
assertions. If you encode a wav into flac format, you get the same data
back:

# compressed w/ flac soul of man track from beatport (tagged and renamed too)
$ flac -dc
breaks/\(soul_of_man\)_foxy_moron_\[original_mix\].flac|md5sum

flac 1.1.4, Copyright (C) 2000,2001,2002,2003,2004,2005,2006,2007  Josh
Coalson
flac comes with ABSOLUTELY NO WARRANTY.  This is free software, and you
are welcome to redistribute it under certain conditions.  Type `flac' for
details.

(soul_of_man)_foxy_moron_[original_mix].flac: done
2f0c4b07172f9c119d66df46d4642069  -

# original soul of man track from beatport
$ md5sum 93020_Foxy_Moron_Original_Mix.wav
2f0c4b07172f9c119d66df46d4642069  93020_Foxy_Moron_Original_Mix.wav

You should probably go educate yourself a bit about FLAC, WAV, lossless
compression, get some data and back up your assertions with that data.

Note that WAV is just a container format for PCM. It can be losslessly
compressed too.

Since the md5s aren't changing above, there is *no* loss to the data.

For more on the theory behind all this, go read:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Md5
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wav
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FLAC

You can go get tools that allow you to test this empirically, don't just
believe it because I'm telling that it is so.

-- 
Holt Sorenson
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com
myspace.com/hsomusic

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
