MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beatport DJ? Program to rename your songs

Yeah, basically with lossless compression you are trading off less disk 
space and network bandwidth use for slightly more CPU use during playback 
(and substantially more CPU for the initial compression).

As Holt mentions below, CPU is getting cheaper a lot faster than disk and 
bandwidth, so it's a good tradeoff.

Additionally, there are cases when disk space is at a premium, such as on 
my 4GB nano. It can hold 12 albums in Apple Lossless format, vs. 6 in WAV. 
That's a meaningful difference to me.

On Thu, Aug 09, 2007 at 04:37:09PM -0700, SE/30 wrote:
>I love it when people spout claims that are purely ignorant...

>'makes ignoring other ridiculous things they claim *that* much easier ;)

I will point out that Matthew generally has the right idea about
compression, he just had a misunderstanding about FLAC.

My aim isn't/wasn't to 'serve' Matthew and attempt to make
him look ignorant, in fact I initially wasn't going to reply
to his 'flac what the fuck' message since I thought it was silly
to get into it in depth. I saw one or two other messages that
tried to clear shit up and he didn't bite, so I threw out an
email with data.

Matthew still might have a reason (possibly qualitative?) for his point
of view.

On Thu, Aug 09, 2007 at 04:39:24PM -0700, Van Mundegaarde wrote:
>I love it when douchebag techno-geeks argue about crap that very few people 
>give a good god-damn about.

Since I think this list is a mix of a lot of people, including
producers, I think this is fair game. If all you're doing is
throwing down tracks on a couple of CDJs and technics, my approach
is probably over the top (I acknowleged as much in a reply to one
of your emails earlier). Pure cocaine at the top of the audio chain,
since you're about to do a bunch of DSP (both in hardware and software
nowadays), is the best shit out there. FLAC is one way to get pure
cocaine. AIFF-C and others work as well.

FWIW, people get far more into this than we have in this thread.

For example, see:
http://www.hydrogenaudio.org/forums/lofiversion/index.php/t47922.html

>Being right was never cooler I bet!

Being right is so seventh grade.

Again, my aim was to educate.

On Thu, Aug 09, 2007 at 04:56:11PM -0700, Uncle Noah wrote:
>
>I love the irony of using the term "techno-geeks" as a
>slur on a rave listserv

nerds of the world untie^H^H^Hite.

>I also love the use of the term douchbag, but really
>prefer when folks just haul off and call each other
>"douche"

Can I get a 3 day old rotting douche, anyone? Let's start
having fun. I think I'll go grab my 'hello my name is fuck
you' sticker from last weekend and put it on.

Maybe after we finish with name calling we can devolve into
'ur-mom' jokes?

-- 
Holt Sorenson
hso@hsomusic.com

admission: i was confused about how FLAC works.  what I said is correct for
probably 90% of popular compression formats though, and I thought FLAC works
the same.  comments about storage are true, though that depends on a
person's finances and computing experience.  now that I know more about how
it works, my opinion is better informed, everyone's happy, and I can
continue not preferring FLAC.  sounds better than mp3 and AAC (or whatever
that horrible Sony proprietary format is), now my biggest problem with it is
lack of support for FLAC in many popular media players/programs (which I
admit is probably old information and I'm guessing that newer models are
updating with better compatibility).

I might look into FLAC, if anyone can recommend a good compression program.
storage isn't a giant issue for me because I do plenty of non-music
computing and I can afford $100 for an extra 400GB if I ever run low on
space.  I do keep a good bit of music compressed, mostly albums, live sets,
compilations, and the like, since live sets especially only seem to come as
mp3.  I try to keep my DJ'ing library uncompressed, though sometimes I have
to settle for 320kbps mp3 sources.  Now if beatport would just get rid of
their bullshit "wav handling fee" or whatever....

On 8/9/07, Holt Sorenson <hso@hsomusic.com> wrote:
>

> Since I think this list is a mix of a lot of people, including
> producers, I think this is fair game. If all you're doing is
> throwing down tracks on a couple of CDJs and technics, my approach
> is probably over the top (I acknowleged as much in a reply to one
> of your emails earlier). Pure cocaine at the top of the audio chain,
> since you're about to do a bunch of DSP (both in hardware and software
> nowadays), is the best shit out there. FLAC is one way to get pure
> cocaine. AIFF-C and others work as well.
>
> FWIW, people get far more into this than we have in this thread.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] outlandish claims of gospel

--------------070906040009000307010906
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

After a better than 25 year search, I finally tracked down the legendary 
Clash show at the Palladium on 14th Street in New York City that they 
played on 21 September 1979, about 3 months before "London Calling" was 
released in the United States.

I know everyone that's reading this is familiar with one aspect of it, 
it's the show where this picture http://tinyurl.com/y553zx  was taken.

Now that I've gotten your attention, here it is 
http://isohunt.com/download/19452907/clash+palladium

Great right?

To a point because it's a .flac file, which 448, or so, megs aside, 
presents a raft of technical problems for the average end-user, because 
they're simply not going to jump thru the hoops required to get the damn 
thing to play on their iPhonde.

That's not why they dropped $600+ bucks on it.

For that kind of money, they expect shit to work on demand, and since I 
don't see a $30K wireless electrostatic vacuum tube wireless headphone 
arrangement http://tinyurl.com/36hj9g projecting from anyone's mp3 
player, (for myself I'm happy with my HD 600s, http://tinyurl.com/22gon3 
thank you very much), I just don't see the point in not making a file as 
accessible to as many peeples as possible, so it actually, you know, 
like, be listened to.

I converted the Clash's LC Live At The Palladium  .flac file to .mp3 and 
it's all of 140 megs, and once I figure out how to seed the damn thing 
on bittorrent I'm gonna post it on the internets and I don't think 
anybody that DLs it is going to bitch over the quality of the audio.

Your mileage, as always, may vary.

....

Matthew Johnson wrote:
> admission: i was confused about how FLAC works.  what I said is correct for
> probably 90% of popular compression formats though, and I thought FLAC works
> the same.  comments about storage are true, though that depends on a
> person's finances and computing experience.  now that I know more about how
> it works, my opinion is better informed, everyone's happy, and I can
> continue not preferring FLAC.  sounds better than mp3 and AAC (or whatever
> that horrible Sony proprietary format is), now my biggest problem with it is
> lack of support for FLAC in many popular media players/programs (which I
> admit is probably old information and I'm guessing that newer models are
> updating with better compatibility).
>
> I might look into FLAC, if anyone can recommend a good compression program.
> storage isn't a giant issue for me because I do plenty of non-music
> computing and I can afford $100 for an extra 400GB if I ever run low on
> space.  I do keep a good bit of music compressed, mostly albums, live sets,
> compilations, and the like, since live sets especially only seem to come as
> mp3.  I try to keep my DJ'ing library uncompressed, though sometimes I have
> to settle for 320kbps mp3 sources.  Now if beatport would just get rid of
> their bullshit "wav handling fee" or whatever....
>

If you haven't heard, Acid Totem is putting together our first ever camp out
in beautiful Big Sur!  We have a 5000 watt yorkville rig that will be
churnin' out the bass with views of the surrounding Santa Lucia Mountains
and the majestic Pacific 4000' below.

Aural Perpetrators for the weekend include:
Dov
Adnan
Ripple
RedStickman
Carlos  (pangea / area51)
Eric Sharp
Homero Espinosa
Majitope
Mo Corleone
Evolution CQ

Dirt
Rob Monroy
Mycho
Carlos Alfonzo
Evolution CQ
Idiotbox
Aleks
Flook
Ben Haus
Plasticity
Unityvybe
Kris Kent

$10 tix now available, only 250 tickets will be sold to this gathering
This is a leave no trace event, please pack out whatever you bring.
18+
Festivities begin Friday before sunset
www.acidtotem.net/campout

i'm sure it feels cooler than being an asshole :)

_the asshole_

from his mouth he shat
spittin' words of an asshat
how'd the motha fukka get a head so fat ?
wreakin' and stinkin'
when he shoulda been thinking
pepe le peue couldn't stink like that

mutha fukka is deranged
sensibility estranged
mouth gettin' raped
like a louisanna lane change

but holt shut'm down
his shit now comin' from a frown
matt was merely ignant
but that van's the ass clown

sfr don't play
when you do it like that
got brainiac fukkas
just waitin' on tap
we're shuttin' down, flushin' down
the shit that you shat

git your face some clearisil
take a fucking chill pill
just get rid of that shat
or will bring the vagisil

logic is the king
bring even YOU protection
so fuck your baby rat
and your yeast infection

-=dave

Subject: [sfraves] Work it to the Bone tomorrow SFRavers

Be sure to party hop on saturday, 
cuz we gonna bang some serious deep techno as only Detroit can.  

Check the website/info line for location info tomorrow evening. 

This Saturday, August 11th
Bassaholics Anonymous Presents
Fractured featuring DJ Bone

Get your techno-soul-funk fix.

Bear witness
to one of Detroit techno's original 3 deck magicians live and direct from the Motor City. 

Downtown SF Location.
for more info 415.814.5884
WWW.BASSAHOLICSANONYMOUS.COM 

Only $10 until 1AM
10 PM - Afterhours 

IT WAS SOULFUL. IT WAS FUNKY. WHAT HAPPENED TO THE MUSIC? I REMEMBER WHEN WE USED TO DANCE. TRUE ARTFORM. BASTARDIZED. RESHAPED. REPACKAGED. WATERED DOWN. SOLD OUT. WHAT HAPPENED TO THE SOUL? SOLD OUT. THE SOUL SOLD OUT. BUT NOT THE SOULMAKERS. WE LIVE FOR THIS SHIT. THIS IS OUR SHIT. THIS IS WHAT WE FEEL. THIS IS HOW WE WORK. ITS NOT A GIMMICK. THIS AIN'T NO HYPE. BULLSHIT ASS POSTERCHILD FOR SOME SHIT YOU DIDNT INVENT. SUCKIN THE SOUL OUT OF IT. WATERING IT DOWN. ITS A SHAME. ARE YOU FUNKY WITH THE MACHINES, OR DO THE MACHINES MAKE YOU FUNKY? WHO PROGRAMS WHO? DO THE MACHINES PROGRAM YOU? THIS IS OUR LIFE. THIS IS OUR LOVE. OUR PASSION. 
-DJ BONE

http://www.7mzdt.com/subjectdetroit/mp3/ATTACK37.mp3

This is my single biggest gripe with the majority of events here in SF. 
Headliners going on late as hell. We aren't all 23 years old and have the 
ability to be able to eat piles of drugs and stay out all night - it'd be 
nice to see a headliner come on no later than 1am and get a couple solid 
hours to do their magic. But a 2am start time? That is kinda on the late 
tip...

As much as I love Bone, I will be going to Tonal instead now.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Work it to the Bone tomorrow SFRavers

take your Geritol old man, if i can do it, you can do it!

it's a Saturday night afterhours party, i think putting the headliner
on b4 two would be weird, no? that's when the biggest influx of people
are just getting there after hitting the bars, etc first.

i mean, if it were a weeknight or something, yeah definitely earlier
would be better, but on a weekend in SF isn't 2-4am considered about
the prime slot?  i would consider it as such.

what's everyone else think?

Check out fitting  gifts for grads at Yahoo! Search.

 >Burning Man Art.
 >

 >yourself and devoting untold time to suspend 2 big rigs in the air?  I
 >mean,
 >yeah, it looks cool and all.  But... man! the scale!  I know you have

 >then ask the community for another $20,000... I mean.. there is probalby
 >a lot of other cool art this guy could have done for a more modest budget.
 >
 >I mean, he needs 3 flatbed trucks to get it to the playa?
 >
 >Okay, I am posting this poking fun at the poor guy, but who knows, maybe
 >some sfraves are sympathetic to his cause?  Personally, would rather 
donate
 >money to a battered woman's shelter then this over-wrought peice of BM 
art.
 >But maybe that is just me....
 >
 >-------------------------------
 >
 >SPECIAL ART EDITION
 >
 >Two of our most ambitious honorarium projects for 2007 are BigRigJig by
 >Mike Ross and JIm Mason's  Mechabolic: Cyborg Speculations in Machine
 >Metabolism.
 >
 >Although Burning Man funded both projects, each has exhausted their
 >budget and is in need of financial support. We have never before
 >approached the community for help like this, but we are  unable to
 >further fund these projects, so we are calling on our readers for help
 >in a few ways.
 >
 >Mike Ross of Big Rig Jig - (see the project at http://www.bigrigjig.com
 >- it's literally awesome) - reports:
 >
 >"Things are going well on the project.  We are on schedule, and ramping
 >things up dramatically for the last few weeks.  Several new core crew
 >members just arrived from New York with a burst of energy and
 >enthusiasm.  We are working full time, 7 days a week, from about 2pm to
 >4am (last two nights till 5am, actually).  Its an amazing group of
 >people that can sacrifice months of their lives, working that hard to
 >pull something like this off.  Im lucky to have them around.  And we are
 >all lucky to have Burning Man provide the opportunity for us.
 >
 >Unfortunately, despite our best and continued efforts, we are out of
 >money.  Putting two big rig trucks 40 feet up in the air is enormously
 >difficult, especially when you come from out of town (we moved our
 >entire operation from Brooklyn, NY to California in order to build this
 >sculpture).  We received the majority of our funding from the Burning
 >Man grant, and immediately began seeking additional sources to make up
 >for the remainder of our budget.  But between setting up a new shop,
 >finding our materials in an unfamiliar environment, and actually
 >building the project, our time is stretched thin.   The long and short
 >of it is that we have so far failed to find the additional funding we
 >need.  As of two weeks ago,  the project is being funded by personal
 >credit cards, which is difficult as I have no source of income right
 >now, and have already spent my savings on the project.  If you know of
 >any emergency funding opportunities, or other helpful people or
 >resources, we would be much obliged. You can help with in kind donations
 >of materials, too.
 >
 >If you can help, please contact   mikenon@gmail.com
 >Donate via PayPal to: donate@bigrigjig.com
 >
 >Funding Needs:
 >To meet costs, we need to raise approximately $20,000.  Any donation,
 >large or small, helps.
 >
 >Some specific in kind donations would help reduce this. Wish List:
 >
 >    * I-beams: 72 feet of W14x109 I-beam (or approximate equivalent)
 >    * Road Plates: 5 road plates (or approximate equivalent) borrowed or
 >purchased
 >    * Chrome Truck Accessories, such as: air filter assemblies, exterior
 >"chicken" lights, bumpers, exhaust "stacks", rims
 >    * Lighting: exterior par cans or other lights which can project onto
 >the surface of the sculpture
 >    * 20 kW generator, or approximate equivalent, for use during 2-week
 >pre-event installation
 >    * Transportation Services: 3 full-length flatbeds from Oakland to the
 >playa before the event, and from playa to Oakland afterwards
 >
 >Also, we can always use more volunteers in Oakland of various skill
 >levels, from skilled metal fabricators/welders, to anyone willing to
 >spend a few hours holding a grinder.
 >
 >
 >

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Work it to the Bone tomorrow SFRavers

2-4 is generally peak time for an afterhours, after 4 people start leaving,
before 2 a lot of your party is still showing up, so if you have an out of
town headliner in a two hour slot that'd make the most sense to me.

A

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Work it to the Bone tomorrow SFRavers

Don't get me wrong, I think the locals will be dope too - but honestly, I 
HATE waiting that late for a headliner at a club. At a Rave or something, I 
can see that - but at a night club, I wanna be able to suck back cocktails 
during the headliner's set - and that timeslot doesn't really afford me that 
luxury.

Personal preference, that's all...

Marc(O)

> > > not make more sense to have Bone on earlier in the evening...and I
> > > don't mean opening slot, but fuck.  Oh well.  Have fun.
> > >
> > > c h r i s
> > >
> > >
> > > On Aug 10, 2007, at 1:19 PM, James Hurlbut wrote:

> > > > FOR THIS SHIT. THIS IS OUR SHIT. THIS IS WHAT WE FEEL. THIS IS HOW
> > > > WE WORK. ITS NOT A GIMMICK. THIS AIN'T NO HYPE. BULLSHIT ASS
> > > > POSTERCHILD FOR SOME SHIT YOU DIDNT INVENT. SUCKIN THE SOUL OUT OF
> > > > IT. WATERING IT DOWN. ITS A SHAME. ARE YOU FUNKY WITH THE MACHINES,
> > > > OR DO THE MACHINES MAKE YOU FUNKY? WHO PROGRAMS WHO? DO THE
> > > > MACHINES PROGRAM YOU? THIS IS OUR LIFE. THIS IS OUR LOVE. OUR
> > > > PASSION. -DJ BONE     DOWNLOAD DJ BONE MIXES:
> > > >

Subject: [sfraves] Tony Wilson RIP

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C7DBAC.83133380
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Original URL: http://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/08/11/wilson_obit/


Manchester music impresario dies


By Andrew Orlowski <mailto:andrew.orlowski@theregister.co.uk>
(andrew.orlowski@theregister.co.uk)

Published Saturday 11th August 2007 05:22 GMT

Rare was the day when Anthony Wilson, the Manchester music impresario =
and
local TV presenter who died yesterday, couldn't walk down the street in =
his
home city without a murmur of "wanker" and "cunt". It was as much as a =
part
of the city as the incessant drizzle.

But Wilson revelled in the role of camp, ironic, antihero and played it =
to
the hilt. In interviews in early June, six months after his cancer had =
been
diagnosed, Wilson fretted that Mancunians were suddenly "being nice to =
me".
This was a shock in such a fiercely unsentimental city.

Music lovers visiting Britain from overseas began skipping London in the
1990s, heading straight for what's now recognised as Britain's great =
music
city - and that owed much of that outrageous charm of Tony Wilson.

In the mid-70s Tony Wilson used his influence at Britain's leading
independent TV station Granada to promote The Sex Pistols and a new
generation of punk bands, then put his weight and capital behind a small
independent club and label in the city. Through fluke, good fortune and =
a
fierce pride in promoting local talent - Wilson had a recording sound =
genius
in producer Martin Hannett, a designer in Peter Saville, and a =
charismatic
genius in Joy Division's Ian Curtis - Factory Records became the first =
real
British independent label since Joe Meek's Triumph Records to gain
international kudos. The commercial success of Joy Division (later New
Order) was invested in a "New York style" nightclub, the Hacienda, which
later became a focal point of Britain's coalescence into a dance =
culture.
This bit of history celebrated in Michael Winterbottom's movie 24 Hour =
Party
People - a generous dramatization of Manchester music mythology.

Manchester's rise to prominence as a world music city coincided with
London's decline - and by 1980 the metropolis that gave the world The =
Who
and The Kinks in the 1960s had added nothing but novelty bands (The
Joboxers, Right Said Fred... and Blur) until the creative melting pot =
spewed
forth drum and bass, garage, two step and a mass of urban dance music.

Wilson himself had a famously terrible judgement for music and also, for =
a
Piscean, he was notoriously Aquarian when it came to money. He rarely =
knew
what was happening musically in Manchester (he was wary of The Fall and
declined to sign The Smiths, and promoted folk music just as acid house =
was
taking off) at any given point in its Factory's history, and he rarely =
knew
who was pocketing the readies from his business endeavours.

He revelled in the role of intellectual fop. In Winterbottom's movie, a
cameo Christopher Eccleston playing a drunk recites Petrarchus' cyclical
view of history under a railway to invigorate a dispirited Wilson. In =
real
life, Wilson contradicted Victor Lewis-Smith's contention that Oxbridge
graduates mention their college at dinner parties within seven minutes -
only by invariably mentioning his Cambridge education within the first =
180
seconds of meeting. Wilson insisted a vast portrait hung over the box =
office
over the Hacienda.

Yet for all the pretensions, Wilson forged a link between the Jewish
cultural entrepreneurs of North Manchester - promoters and managers such =
as
Alan Wise and Elliott Rashman, who were heirs to the tradition of =
Charles
Halle (who the Mancunian novelist Anthony Burgess credited with =
"civilising
England") and the hippy South Manchester scene of CP Lee and Bruce =
Mitchell.

Cities need such characters.

In the punk era, Liverpool had Bill Drummond and Manchester, for better =
or
worse, had Wilson - both were relentless promoters. While Drummond came =
and
went (to later burn =A31m for the heck of it, as an "art project" after =
his
pop success with KLF), Wilson, a Salford Catholic, stayed to the end. =
Wilson
never invested a penny outside the city of Manchester. Thirty miles away
over the Pennines, Sheffield had a thriving scene which gave us The =
Human
League and Pulp, and gave a backbone to electro and acid house - but =
lacked
such a svengali as a Drummond or Wilson.

Because Wilson stuck around, with New Order sustaining the Hacienda, he
later basked in the light shone by "Madchester", when "even the white =
boys
learned how to dance". Even if he didn't immediately recognize a trend, =
once
he saw it, he promoted it ferociously. And in losing him, the North of
England lost a great voice.

In 1992 Wilson set up In The City, a music industry schmoozefest to =
which
this reporter was generously given a keynote [transcript
<http://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/09/23/orlowski_interactive_keynote/>
(http://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/09/23/orlowski_interactive_keynote/)] =
-
"just to shake things up".

Wilson was fabulously utopian about the potential of music, never more =
so
than in this quote to biographer Bill Sykes, who's writing a life of the
great scene maker and music promoter Roger Eagle:

"I always think that what Richard Boon and Howard Devoto did bringing =
the
Pistols to Manchester on June 4th [1976] was the same thing as the =
Germans
putting Lenin into a cattle cart and sending the railway train into =
Russia,"
he said last year.

"They sent this firebrand, this spark to fuck up the Russians, which of
course it did. It caused a revolution."

We couldn't ever admit as much on earth, but we'll miss you so much, =
Anthony
H Wilson.=AE

=A9 Copyright 2007=20

=20


------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C7DBAC.83133380--

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Content-Disposition: inline

Personally I'm with Andrew P on this one, if it's an afterhours underground
event then 2-4 is definitely peak.  I know that at some parties I've been to
3-6am was the prime timeslot.  Like when QBAM played back in January or
February, he had just come on when I got there at maybe 2:30 and he was
still pumping out one sick sexy bassline after the next when we left at 6am,
and there was a decent crowd to the end (that particular party is one of the
best I've ever been to and it changed my perspective on the scene, btw,
thanks a ton Andrew).  So I guess it just depends what you're prepared for.
Myself, I love techno and techno simply does not come to the bay area often
enough to miss an opportunity like this.  Although to be fair, I'm stuck
down in Houston, TX until mid-september, and our scene is horseshit so I
haven't even been to a party/concert/event in weeks.

MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Message-ID: <111313.82137.qm@web702.biz.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Beatport DJ?  Program to rename your songs

--0-880885079-1186892395=:82137
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hi all,

Sorry for a followup email.  The original aa.zip that was on http://phillip.freedomring.net didn't work.  I didn't realize what beatport calls the 'mix' is in the original filename.  (I don't actually DJ :))  It now works, and I included a convertwav.bat and convertmp3.bat, so all you need to do now is unzip the contents of aa.zip into the directory of your newly downloaded songs, replace the content of receipt.txt with the information in your beatport email receipt, and run convertwav.bat or convertmp3.bat.  (It also ignores any non-song information, so you can copy the entire receipt into receipt.txt and it will rename the songs properly)

Thanks,
Phillip



Phillip Mispagel <phillip@viberation.com> wrote: Hola,

I wrote a small program to rewrite the filenames of songs you download from beatport.com to include the Track, Artist, and Label.  Thank you Forest Green and Andy Highland for the ideas.

They currently only include the Beatport song ID and Track name, making it very easy to forget who actually wrote the songs.

It's written in Python, and instructions on how to use it and where to get it are here:

http://phillip.freedomring.net

Feel free to modify it at your own will and for your own purposes. :)

-Phillip







--0-880885079-1186892395=:82137--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Work it to the Bone tomorrow SFRavers


DJ Bone was fucking amazing.

Class in session shit, changing it up, tribal funky soulful tweaky robot 
fucking noises from a guy who went from cool to badass over his over 4 
hours on deck (got on around 2, ran out of records around 6:15).  All at 
an old school renegade location that's been going strong for over ten 
years now.  Morning had shit eating grins all around, seriously great 
times.

Just plain badass.  No cheerleading, no posturing, just in the zone 313 
delivery from a fucking pimp with a head-down "make it work" ethic.  Only 
gripes I can come up with at all are:

* I didn't play :)
* my feet are screwed today from 250+ minutes of dancing my ass off
* sound could have used some chest defibrolating bass
* Eric was hitting on the girl I met up with there (more funny than 
anything).  Was awesome that she came out at all, she's a self professed 
"not into techno" person and ended up dancing more than she had in 5 years.  
Whoops, convert!
* there were two morons on the dancefloor screaming their heads off, 
whooping it up as new records would come in.  Luckily for me, one of them 
was me so it's easier to forgive them.

He played 100% vinyl, and in talking with him after the show he had a 
great quote about modern production/dj mixing stuff... "these technologies 
that should be making stuff better are just making it easier, we need to 
do what they did back in the day with those limited devices with what's 
available now".

Schooled.
andyw

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

 I think this Tonal party is one they are going to talk about for years to come. It had an awesome vibe allready just to get pushed over the edge when Dj Rap decided to show for an unscheduled dj set. I think the party could have easily gone another couple of hours. I will love to see the Tonal parties try and or accomplish toping this one.

to.  They've been going at approximately the rate of one per month, so don't
worry, there will be plenty more.  I was out of town for this one but I'm
looking forward to the next already.

On 8/12/07, AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
>
>
> DJ Bone was fucking amazing.
>
> Class in session shit, changing it up, tribal funky soulful tweaky robot
> fucking noises from a guy who went from cool to badass over his over 4
> hours on deck (got on around 2, ran out of records around 6:15).  All at
> an old school renegade location that's been going strong for over ten
> years now.  Morning had shit eating grins all around, seriously great
> times.
>
> Just plain badass.  No cheerleading, no posturing, just in the zone 313
> delivery from a fucking pimp with a head-down "make it work" ethic.  Only
> gripes I can come up with at all are:
>
> * I didn't play :)
> * my feet are screwed today from 250+ minutes of dancing my ass off
> * sound could have used some chest defibrolating bass
> * Eric was hitting on the girl I met up with there (more funny than
> anything).  Was awesome that she came out at all, she's a self professed
> "not into techno" person and ended up dancing more than she had in 5
> years.
> Whoops, convert!
> * there were two morons on the dancefloor screaming their heads off,
> whooping it up as new records would come in.  Luckily for me, one of them
> was me so it's easier to forgive them.
>
> He played 100% vinyl, and in talking with him after the show he had a
> great quote about modern production/dj mixing stuff... "these technologies
> that should be making stuff better are just making it easier, we need to
> do what they did back in the day with those limited devices with what's
> available now".
>
> Schooled.
> andyw
>

I know there's some BBQ lovin' beer drinkers on here.  If you are, and
you're free this saturday-  let's just say you can't pass this up!

5th Annual Russian River Revial Festival
on the Russian River in Guerneville
All you can eat and drink for $35 advance, $40 at the gate.
27 breweries
25 BBQ teams

1-5pm
www.stumptown.com/revival

Breweries on site

No worries on the door thing.  I was just more like, "whoa -
these guys were promoting within our party (on the same
night)".  I understand the raising the price thing, tho - it's
a good marketing decision to ensure people get to your party
early.  :)

hour, but it worked out anyway, as we were pretty beat and left
Tonal early-ish to get some food.

Did you guys happen to record his set?  I'd love to hear it -
Nico's been talking about Bone for years, and I was really
looking forward to his set...

Thanks!

Ah...

You missed out!  I brought FOUR different kinds of my beer
along:

- IPA
- Dutch Strong Ale
- Porter
- Summer Ale

Everyone agreed that the IPA was too carbonated, but tasted
good.  The Dutch Strong Ale was a favorite, as was the Porter. 
But the real winner was the Summer Ale.  :)

I still have a case of the Summer Ale left - I'll bring some
out next time!

m

Subject: [sfraves] Burning Man Spot

------=_Part_35683_10631773.1187056983268
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Hello, my name is Peter, and I've been in the rave scene for about a year
and a half.  I will be going to Burning Man on August 27th and have a free
spot.  The price of the ticket will be 260 dollars, plus i'll give you a
ride and we can split the cost of provisions neccessary for a week of
survival in the nevada desert.  HOWEVER, you MUST be able to get yourself to
sacramento.  You can take a train or a bus, it's really not that expensive
to do so if you do not have a car.  Please let me know if anyone is
interested in this sort of thing, I'd be more than happy to have a fellow
raver accompany me in the insanity of art and culture that is Burning Man.
Hope everyone is having a great day :)

------=_Part_35683_10631773.1187056983268--

loooooong!!!  I mean... i kinda got there late 'cause i had to help out w/

yeah... i started dancing!!!  It was the DJ b4 DJ BONE when i got there!

outta town were there & it was Family filled!!!  Good to see Miki & Mark
again after a looooooong time!!!  YAAAY!  Oh yeah... & it was Awesome

damn thick & it was all kindsa Dope!  There was even a 2nd chill room in

people in that bathroom takin pictures of each other!  I mean... yeah...
just Hello 2Day Yummy alll night!!!

mean.,.for 4-5 hours, he fuckin' rocked it HAAAAAARD!!!  I coulda sworn he
dropped 1 Acid Techno Choon in his set, but yeah, it was hard, alota

songs, poppy techno, evil techno.oooh man.. all kinds.. .I Loved it!!  I
was in Heaven!!!

IN the morning when i was walkin' to BART, there were all these people on
ummm.. Main street... lol.. All Filipinos, some floats... then I saw this
Wild 94.9 van there... so i chilled w/ the person driving & well.. tried
to see if he had any yummy dance music CDs to give me.. none, but had a
good early moring conversation w/ him!  I even got free donuts!! 
Aparetnly it was a YUM!!!  But yeah... i'm still.. even up to now.. on
this mondo Techno Yummy High still 'cause that rave was just the medicine
i needed!!  I Love ya Mikalow & James & crew.. Thank U sooo much for
another historic night of Awesome in 2007!!!  this one is fer sure just
Yeah.. I got mondo fuckin' BONED.. hard,  & I'm still feeling it man!!! 
Thank U DJ BONE for that Bad Ass Fuckin' Set!!!

Subject: [sfraves] Inside the Freqbox:: This Weekend :: John Selway @ AsiaSF

Inside the Freqbox:: This Weekend :: John Selway @ AsiaSF
Full listings at www.freqbox.net

Friday, if you're into the mutations of techno, electro and disco,
catch NY's John Selway at in an above ground venue (Asia SF) with
supporting acts from Nikola Baytala and host Dj Andre Lucero. Who knew
Asia SF would host techno downstairs? Let's check it out....

Saturday intimate downtown UG spots - 58 Tehama hosts "Platform" with
local mofos from Kontrol + Auralism, plus Vadim from Broklyn's
minimalist outfit "Less".


:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::

Friday: 8/17 John Selway - Asia SF
Fiction presents=85
b e l o w
Friday, August 17, 2007
@ AsiaSF (downstairs)
201 9th Street @ Howard, SF

John Selway - CSM, Memory Boy, Selway Music, NYC
Nikola Baytala - Robsoul, [KONTROL], Bionic
Andr=E9 Lucero - watered!, fiction
The Worker - stateless, fiction

4 sick DJ's rocking the basement with techno electro italo mutant
disco from below

www.myspace.com/fictionsf

:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::=
:::::::::


Saturday: 8/18/07 Platform all night underground event.

Sammy D (Dirtybird Records, KontrolSF)
Vadim (less, NYC)
Nikola Baytala (SWAT, KontrolSF)
Jason Short (Auralism Residents)
Craig Kuna (ESDJCO, KontrolSF)
Dima (58Tehama, Mikrofon)

10 p.m. - ??????
58 Tehama St., SF(between 1st and 2nd, Howard and Folsom)
$5 before 11 p.m 10$ after
www.dworkz.com/showcase/platform/ Please: RESPECT THE SPACE


Coming up:

Saturday: 8/25 : The out of the way but worth the trek destination,
the Compound hosts Siteholder Records' showcase from Chicago. Expect
tricked out techno toys and sweaty ambitions from Billy Dalessandro
and friends.

More info at: www.siteholder.net/


Burning Man: 8/25 through 9/2:

For those exiting the asphalt for dustier destinations, get the best
multidimensional psyched out techno on the playa at 1:11.

The Sapphire Portal, hosted by Brooklyn's Wolf + Lamb will feature the
best minimal-philes in the country. More info on the project here:

harlanemil.com/sapphireportal.html

Subject: [sfraves] Question....

Just a question for those out there in promotions land (or even if you're 
not a promoter).

If you knew someone (a friend) who wanted to book a headliner for a party, 
and they arranged the booking, and then they came to you and asked you to 
help with the booking fees because they couldn't afford them on their own, 
and you agreed to split the costs with the person - then they turned around 
and had someone ELSE pay part of what THEY were going to pay, but left you 
still paying half (as was originally arranged) - would that be fair?

And let's pretend that the person that asked for your help didn't ASK you 
about this, they just went and did it...

What are your opinions on this subject?

To: Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY110-F36DFFEE1EE5256E9B350DE85DF0@phx.gbl>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Message-ID: <894050.67570.qm@web32005.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question....



As long as he came up with his half, I wouldn't really
care where he got it.  If he pulled it out of a bank,
sold his car, pimped his Aunt Tilly, wn it in a dice
game, borrowed it from a loan shark, etc. wouldn't
matter to me as long as he had his half in-hand when
he needed to.  How he gets his money is his own
business.

Now, if this side-deal of his somehow affected *my*
ability to make my money back (or cut into *my* profit
percentage) *then* I'd be pissed.  But if it's just a
matter of where he's getting his scratch from, I could
care less. 

  

--- Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
wrote:

> Just a question for those out there in promotions
> land (or even if you're 
> not a promoter).
> 
> If you knew someone (a friend) who wanted to book a
> headliner for a party, 
> and they arranged the booking, and then they came to
> you and asked you to 
> help with the booking fees because they couldn't
> afford them on their own, 
> and you agreed to split the costs with the person -
> then they turned around 
> and had someone ELSE pay part of what THEY were
> going to pay, but left you 
> still paying half (as was originally arranged) -
> would that be fair?
> 
> And let's pretend that the person that asked for
> your help didn't ASK you 
> about this, they just went and did it...
> 
> What are your opinions on this subject?
>

From: Eric Spire <ericspire@yahoo.com>
To: Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org

Message-ID: <304055.22134.qm@web36813.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question....

The answer is simple: If there is no pecking order in
relation to payback and/or profits, it should not
matter a bit. If, on the other hand, there is a
payback agreement which makes one person's money a
higher priority than the others, it could go terribly
wrong. Ultimately, it comes down to getting paid back.
If everything is sorted out correctly in the end, then
it makes no difference at all.

E

I would probably be less butt-hurt if it weren't for the fact that there was 
no communication with me regarding it whatsoever, and there was no attempt 
made to get help for part of what *I* was ponying up.

Like, rather than me paying $250 and him paying $250 and the other person 
tossing in their $100 to round it out.

Just seems like if you ask someone to help you out, and they are doing so - 
the least you can do is communicate shit with them.

And on top of that, guess who isn't getting any credit for the 
booking....yea, that'd be me too. So I pony up the largest sum of cash, but 
no credit, no communication.

I'm with Eric and Uncle Noah on this one.

It really doesn't affect too much unless this other person goes to "first 
paid back" rule.  We have several small investors in our events some of them 
being people or friends or even some of our parents.  There deffinatly is an 
order as to who gets paid back first and thats important.

Whether his half of the money came from him or not to me doesn't make too 
big of a difference as long as you still get paid back in a timely manner.

Paul

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Eric Spire" 
To: "Van Mundegaarde" ; 
Sent: Thursday, August 16, 2007 4:53 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question....


> The answer is simple: If there is no pecking order in
> relation to payback and/or profits, it should not
> matter a bit. If, on the other hand, there is a
> payback agreement which makes one person's money a
> higher priority than the others, it could go terribly
> wrong. Ultimately, it comes down to getting paid back.
> If everything is sorted out correctly in the end, then
> it makes no difference at all.
>
> E

On Thu, 16 Aug 2007 16:08:29 -0700, Van Mundegaarde  
<electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:

> Just a question for those out there in promotions land (or even if  
> you're not a promoter).
>
> If you knew someone (a friend) who wanted to book a headliner for a  
> party, and they arranged the booking, and then they came to you and  
> asked you to help with the booking fees because they couldn't afford  
> them on their own, and you agreed to split the costs with the person -  
> then they turned around and had someone ELSE pay part of what THEY were  
> going to pay, but left you still paying half (as was originally  
> arranged) - would that be fair?
>
> And let's pretend that the person that asked for your help didn't ASK  
> you about this, they just went and did it...
>
> What are your opinions on this subject?

That's entirely "fair"- this person is trying to get things together and  
likely is working to distribute money as best he can-
If you're worried about him being no longer on the hook, then it's not  
someone you want to lend money to in the first place :)

I wholeheartedly agree if you don't carry yourself around like a =20
victim you won't attract the criminals, in fact you're likely to ward =20
them off for the most part.

Quoting Van Mundegaarde <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>:

> There's a "lack of balance on the streets" cuz folks of the darker
> variety have been shoved into the streets much moreso than little
> crackers...
>
> But I grew up in the dirty District (DC), aka Chocolate City, and I
> have spent mad time in the seedier parts there, Baltimore, Oakland,
> Denver, and to a lesser extent SF - and as long as you don't carry
> yourself like a victim, 9 times out of ten you won't be one. Not saying
> there aren't exceptions to that rule - but you need to be aware of your
> surroundings, and if you are in the 'hood, you need to watch your ass.
>
> I hate to say it, but I have little sympathy for folks who put
> themselves in harm's way and then wonder why bad shit happens to them.
> It still sucks if it happens, but c'mon - don't go wandering around the
> 'hood if you don't want to get rolled.

>
>

> > The answer is simple: If there is no pecking order in
> > relation to payback and/or profits, it should not
> > matter a bit. If, on the other hand, there is a
> > payback agreement which makes one person's money a
> > higher priority than the others, it could go terribly
> > wrong. Ultimately, it comes down to getting paid back.
> > If everything is sorted out correctly in the end, then
> > it makes no difference at all.

for those of you not able to head down to Santa Cruz, some buddies of mine
are throwing an all night underground after the boat with some good
techno/minimal/tech-house.  we'll also be collecting donations for our float
at this year's LoveFest!  go techno!

details here:
http://www.dworkz.com/showcase/platform/flyer.jpg

it's gonna be a crazy weekend of music. john selway @ asiasf, and mr.c @
mighty tonight, the boat and that UG tomorrow, then another dirtybird park
party on sunday. fun fun fun.  hope to see some of you out and about.  by
the way, for those of you who haven't met me, i was that big midwestern
doofus serving drinks at the DJ BONE party last weekend. if you see me
around come say hi and introduce yourself.

peas---->GB

Subject: [sfraves] Deep house@Blowfish sushi tonight. 

Hey Guys,

just a quick heads up for those that live in the SJ area and may or may not 
be going out tonight. I have the pleasure of playing at blowfish tonight and 
will be playing some deep house which is rare to hear my play these days... 
Well it sounds weird me even saying it, but yea I will be playing some 
groovy early night thumpers for those that want to get there drank and eat 
on before the big club night. Or just want to chill and have a more quiet 
evening listening to some good music. Some of the other jocks on the bill 
are the earwacks boys crew of DJ's with various sounds. But im sure you can 
expect deep to funky house from the others on the bill as well..

So if you have the means get your ass on down to blowfish tonight. I will be 
playing from 10-11


See some of ya tonight!!

Macadio

Subject: [sfraves] funkin' italo shiznitz

you gotta hear this.. it will be stuck in your head for quite some time.

we've been listening to italo disco all summer cause our neighbor is mad 
for it.. that and brazillian 'funk'. 4 days ago on a lark we decided to 
make an italo track of our own. i wrote crappy lyrics and put them into 
babblefish to italian from english and then retranslated them into 
english, then fixed the grammar a hair. chel-c wrote the music and 
cleaned up the vocal score. our roommate recorded and cleaned up the 
track in cubase. our other neighbor sang the lyrics after several sake 
shots. and lo! a crappy stereotypical homo-erotic italo disco track.

http://myspace.com/chelcfaithmusic

aside from the lyrics being so piss poor its not a bad track. but hey 
that's the fun of it. enjoy.\


sean

defsf.com

On 8/17/07, Sean Ocean <seanocean@defsf.com> wrote:
> you gotta hear this.. it will be stuck in your head for quite some time.
>
> we've been listening to italo disco all summer cause our neighbor is mad
> for it.. that and brazillian 'funk'. 4 days ago on a lark we decided to
> make an italo track of our own. i wrote crappy lyrics and put them into
> babblefish to italian from english and then retranslated them into
> english, then fixed the grammar a hair. chel-c wrote the music and
> cleaned up the vocal score. our roommate recorded and cleaned up the
> track in cubase. our other neighbor sang the lyrics after several sake
> shots. and lo! a crappy stereotypical homo-erotic italo disco track.
>
> http://myspace.com/chelcfaithmusic
>
> aside from the lyrics being so piss poor its not a bad track. but hey
> that's the fun of it. enjoy.\
>

hope you had a fun time in celebrating..

Joseph Frederick in his suspension for showing a "Bong Hits
4 Jesus" banner.

sick sick breakbeats and tech-funk!

Subject: [sfraves] My INtergalactic Lastweekend Weekend Review :n)

OK.. so my weekend started when i left my house @ around 6PM & rode a bus
to a bus, a bus to the BART, a BART train to a BART train, from BART
walked to Caltrain, & from Caltrain to ummm... Santa Clara!!  On CalTrain,
I met Alfonzo ( i think that's how his names is pronounced), this dude
from Switzerland & was on a Student Visa or something Traveling around the
Country!!  He was a Very fun guy!! :)  When i got to the Sunnyvale
station, some stoner guy from some hick state who travelled to Cali via
Peace Corps then decided to stay here let me use his phone to call Terry
to pick me up (area code 814, where is that?)... then Terry picked me up &
YAAAAAAAY.. Terry.. Thank U & Paula soooooo much for everything again this
past weekend!!!

So Saturday, the BIG HUGE MONDO day!  Like well.. we got to Civic
Auditorium, well, i got there with Big J (1 of the promoters) around
2:30-3ish & helped with what i can to set up... then at 6PM SPACEGIRLS 2
took off... well.. actually.. me & my Homiegirl/ Baby Sis Ethel went to go
eat @ some Mexican Resturaunt for a bit 'cause we needed food, but when we
got back.. it was non stop!!

So like the contest winners & Debut performnces for 4 new Spacegirls
happened the 1st two sets i guess... then oooh yeah... they had Groovy
sets, but tbh, it got more ummm... terbulant when Amber got on the decks
in the main room.. oooooooh fuck yeah.. i was there her whole set and
lol.. I recognizeda lota old Techno she dropped & new Techno choonz...
YUM!!!  CandyFly went on next & well... she fucked it up more.. i mean.. i
remember her spinning more Techno & YUM!!  Actually... instead of being
onthe dance floor this time.. i was kinda like on stage most the whole
time dancing w/ Terri :P  Then Forest Went on after that & played alota
ElectroHouse!!  I mean... it was weird & fun music & ooh my gosh.. I Loved
it!!!  Then like ummm... Shortee was on next & ooh Fuck.. she tore that
fucki'n Spaceship up in to like damn pieces.. JUNGLE!!  I Loved it
sooooooo much!!!  Then her last track, she stopped spinning Jungle, put on
a breaks track, then started scratching & just did that 'til her set was
done!!!

OK.. & Shortee.. she is too damn fun to hang out with.. we spent like the
whole day/night laughing, makin jokes, & just kickin' it!!!  I mean..
during sound check when oooh oh oh oh... so this is kinda fun.. so the set
up for DJs on stage was Dope & weird... like there were 3 DJ set ups.. DJ
Spacegirl (no really, that's her name, not a Spacecgirl DJ) had her live
PA set up in the front, the CDJs & table were in the middle DJ area, & in
the back was Shortee's DJ set up....

There was a side room that was Jungle & Breaks!  From that ro0m, like Miss
Jag from Arizona.. like her & I met like 3-4 years ago when i was over
there... so we had alot to talk about & she like updated a few of us on
the scene out in AZ & how it's doing!!  Did u know that House DJs, like
it's hard for HOuse DJs out in AZ to get gigs 'cause something like
promoters who throw multi room/ genre events refuse to have house in
them.. so that's kinda odd :\ I do feel bad that i didn't get to talk to
Bexxie or really check out alot of her set.. I mean.. i was in the room
when she spun & danced a while!!  But i dunno.. like her & her husband
like were acting weird & didn't really socialize?!

Ofcourse it was fun kickin' it w/ My Ambertime, CandyFly, Buglady, &
Forest! LMAO... yeah... many a good drunk times w/ them... ok.. that's all
i'm gonna say about that.. Hello 2day!!!

Yeah... ofcourse it was a big ass Candy party & oooooooh man.. ok.. so i'm
walkin' like to the front of the auditorium to the entry hall place to
wait for :codetv to show up 'cause we decided that we were gonna do a
show, anywaze.. yeah... I went in the entry hall & right away... i saw
this like 40-50 Candy puddle like right almost from the middles of the
room to the wall.. it was Cute but like kinda scary @ the same time... but
i did meet alota Gropovy kids & it was fun!!  Oh mY goodness man..
aloooooota people i ain't seen in forever either decided to pop up too!! 
That was Dope!!

But yeah... :codetv, we were there.. i mean.. we ain't done that many
shows this year & i just thought it was a good way to get back in the
swing of things!  This show shold be editted w/in like 3-4 weeks!  LoL...
alota crazy moments were actually caught when I did interviews w/ some of
the Space Girls!

Overall, it was a fun party... as for the SG2 afterparty.. long story
short, the owner land owner basically kept changing his prices of what the
promoters were suppose to pay him... after 2 weeks of negotiations & a
list of what the owner dude wanted, everything totaled to $8000 & yeah...
that weas too much to spend on another production for the night... so
that's why the afterparty didn't happen!!!

YAAAY!!!  OK.. So Fun!!  I hope y'alls last weekend was Dope too!!  Ummm..
i dunno where i 'm gonna be this weekend.. but hopefully I'll see some of
y'all!!  Unka, call me & gimme the 411 girl!!

Love U All!!!

Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] Angry Revellers Besiege Cop Shop

Over a hundred ravers laid siege to Yarmouth police station last
weekend and attempted to smash their way in, after police seized a
sound system and arrested three people transporting it to a free party.

Press reports said frightened cops barricaded themselves inside as
ravers threw beer cans at the station before retreating to throw a
party in a nearby industrial estate. Police reinforcements in riot
gear subsequently broke up the event, going on to impound 44
party-goers' cars 'as evidence'.

"By attacking the police station, the organisers of this event have
shown a total disregard for the rule of law," Norfolk Deputy Chief
Constable Ian Learmouth told local newspaper the Norfolk Evening News.

"We have seen some really sinister elements tonight, following a
police car back to the station and besieging the station. We will not
tolerate that behaviour. If you are planning to organise an unlicensed
musical event in this county, expect us to turn up, take away your kit
and pursue a prosecution," he promised.

The confrontation occurred two days before BBC TV show Crimewatch
featured a rogue's gallery of revellers wanted following a similarly
violent altercation in Essex last summer which resulted in 64 police
officers being injured (as well as a number of ravers and one sniffer
dog).

Essex police said officers were also terrified as partygoers fought
them with scaffolding poles and bottles, the BBC reported.

"It is no exaggeration when I say many of the police men and women who
were deployed that night feared for their lives. They were faced with
unacceptable levels of violence for no other reason than they were
police officers doing their job," Detective Superintendent Simon
Dinsdale told The Cambridge News.

"The people responsible for that violence are dangerous people and
must be found."

Unless I'm mistaken, they're just different brand names. Percs, vics,
whatever all come in the standard 5mg,7.5mg, and 10mg forms. In any case
they suck because they're polluted with dirty ass ibuprofen. That's why I
prefer ocs, same shit, but without the ibuprofen and about 80mg per as
opposed to 10.

:-)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: rant for today...what's yours?

My gf and I of 2.5 years broke up because she wants to move to the state of 
Washington, whether I come or not.  If her and I had an epic bond of 
complete acceptance and understanding, with some compassion sprinkled in, 
I'd move for her in a heartbeat.

But she's moving back home for the same reasons I wanna stay.  My friends 
and my family.

Life kinda sucks right now.  But I feel better in sharing.

love always

n i c o

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed

yup.

Moore's Law at work.

As an exercise I pretended that Moore's Law never stops and I asked 
myself where computer  CPU power will be in the year 2107 with today's 5 
ghz machines as the starting point, with a doubling every 2.3 years.

http://www.theinquirer.net/default.aspx?article=39522
5 ghz * (2^(100/2.3))

It's a 10 *trillion* ghz machine.

That kind of CPU power will be able to do all sorts of tracking shit, 
when it comes to shit.

Hell, the tens of millions of networked10 ghz machines that cost $1k 
apiece that are just a few scant years away are coming to a local PD 
near you and they'll definitely be able to stay  on  top of when, and 
where, you pee.

Among other things....

buh buh baybee u ain't seen nuthin' yet.

bye bye.



dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
> Its worth mentioning that by using properly located sensors placed within the sewer network, these chemicals could possibly be traced to specific neighborhoods or even concievably a specific home or toilet. 
>
> And the technologies required for such a sensor network are already being developed for the purpose of protecting water systems from bio-chemical attack and tracking pollutants in the environment.
>
> E.g. http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~jure/pubs/detect-kdd07.pdf 
> http://scitation.aip.org/getabs/servlet/GetabsServlet?prog=normal&id=JWRMD5000131000003000237000001&idtype=cvips&gifs=yes
> http://www.cs.ucsb.edu/~suri/Workshop06/guestrin.pdf
>
> Such sensors can be placed on small mobile robotic platforms that are already under devlopment, and could be moved or reconfigured in situ to optimally locate and track specific sources.
>
> http://www.ais.fraunhofer.de/~eric/Rome99-1.pdf
> http://www.faulhaber-group.com/n222610/n.html
> http://www.sewerobots.de/en/einleitung.html
>
> Peace,

Nah. Hydrocodone (2-Norco 10s) FTW. =0D
 =0D
Two years ago I was in the worst pain in my life. I fell onstage during
rehearsal landing on my wrist and then re-injured it a day later. I bruis=
ed
a nerve and possibly cracked a bone. It hurt so friken bad. Two rounds of
Morphine by IV in the ER did NOTHING. The Dr's couldn't understand why. T=
hey
gave me a heavy duty dose of Norco and some anti barf pills and I was goo=
d
to go.=0D
 =0D
I have no idea why the Norcos worked and the Morphine didn't seeing how t=
hey
are related. Oh well.=0D
 =0D
Jennifer=0D

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: rant for today...what's yours?



It's strange, been injured a bunch this year (broken foot back in March,
no sooner did I get out of the cast to get rearended and pushed into another
car for a case of whiplash, and this week my left eye epithelium decided to
loosen from the cornea), and finding pain meds to be utterly useless.  I've
ended up off the drugs within a couple days and for the eye didn't even
bother asking for anything to take home.  All they mostly did was make me
a little drowsy, but then I'd wake up in the middle of the night, agitated,
when they wore off.  Was less trouble to just deal with the pain.  Not being
able to dance since March was harder than enduring any pain.

Starting to think cybernetic replacements would be a nice option, though.  I
guess technically, the screw holding my foot together does qualify me as
part-man,part-machined. :)

Let's get down to brass tacks here gentlemen. . . How much is there to
*really* say about electronic music?

It's got bass, it mixes well with drugs, it's safe to say everyone here
likes it. . . Anything beyond that goes into the land of petty party drama.

In reference to the original post, until the fucks running the country right
now are out of power we don't have any reason to celebrate. Sure, Gonzales
resigned, but they'll just replace him with someone worse. Remember when
everyone thought Ashcroft was as bad as it could get? Only to hear a few
months ago that he actually had to take a stand defending the constitution
against the man that just resigned? The quality of their appointments gets
worse over time, not better. . . If anything you should be scared of who
they're going to pick next.

My god.

Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] Swiss techno in S.F. Friday - Marius Neukom @ Anu

Germany might be the brain of Europe's techno scene but Switzerland is
where the heart is.

After a decade influencing Switzerland's warmer, dubbier techno scene
through his esteemed radio show ComfortNoise, Marius Newkom aka
New.Com brings his craft state-side.

Friday, August 31:
::Filter:: at Anu :: feat. Marius Neukom//DJ New.Com [ComfortNoise, Zurich]
with Filter residents Kontakt + Solekandi

9:00 PM - 2:00 AM
Free before 11:00 PM
$5 after 11:PM

Anu
6th St (btw Market and Mission)
San Francisco Bay Area, California

Download New.Com's August Radio Show:
http://www.comfortnoise.com/trex/p45_radio_august-07-show_(www.p45.ch).mp3

www.comfortnoise.com
www.p45.ch
www.audioasyl.net
www.myspace.com/filtersf

"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is nothing
but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look and look
and look at all those X's..."

"And?"

"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."

-Kurt Vonnegut

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
visible."

  Fire ignites Burning Man figure; arson suspected
  Mercury News
  Article Launched: 08/28/2007 09:41:17 AM PDT
  
 
  
                            var requestedWidth = 0;                       
                       if(requestedWidth > 0){          document.getElementById('articleViewerGroup').style.width = requestedWidth + "px";                      document.getElementById('articleViewerGroup').style.margin = "0px 0px 10px 10px";                     }                      One person is reportedly in custody following the early igniting of the Burning Man figure this morning at the annual arts festival in Black Rock City, Nevada.   Black Rock City firefighters responded to calls from the event at 2:58 a.m. and took about 23 minutes to douse the blaze, according to the Reno Gazette-Journal. The fire damaged but did not destroy the figure, which is set to be burned on the last day of the festival, on Saturday, the newspaper's Web site said.   No one was injured in the fire, and arson investigators remain on the scene, according to the site.   Calls to festival organizers were not immediately returned.

this was all i could find. an mp3 of one side of an old tape!  this shit's
over 10 years old, folks, not that ghetto (or as they now call it, "juke")
has changed all that much.

when i made that comment, btw, it was based on nothing other than seeing dj
slugo back in the day and always having a blast. similar style to funk, jus=
t
with less wrecks.  and the nastiest of all of em!

uploaded for your pleasure. enjoy.

http://www.kontrolsf.com/AUD/dj_slugo_-_freaks_like_it_raw_(side_a).mp3

--->gb

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Wed)

--

If you ask 100 people what kind of government is America supposed to
be, 99% of them will tell you, a democracy.  America is supposed to be
a democracy.  But that's a lie.  That's an illusion.  The word
democracy is not written into the Constitution one time, it's not in
the Bill of Rights, it's not in the Declaration of Independence.

The Founding Fathers *hated* the idea of a democracy.  They thought it
was the worst form of government there is, and I agree with them.
Because in a democracy, 51% of the people control 49% of the people.
If you're part of the 49%, you're not free.

America was founded as a constitutional republic.  And in that
constitutional republic, 99% of the people can't take away the rights
of 1%.  You have your rights because you're born with them.  You have
god-given human rights that no one can take away.  The government, the
majority, no matter who you are, I can't take away your rights!

- Aaron Russo

Subject: [sfraves] bsp: Sat.Sept.1st [KONTROL] w/ John Tejada LIVE!

------=_Part_226_5082192.1188368728996
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

Saturday, September 1st, 2007

[ K O N T R O L ]

minimal techno + avant-house
every 1st Saturday @ The Endup


featuring from Los Angeles:

JOHN TEJADA  :  LIVE!

( Palette Recordings . Pokerflat . Playhouse
7th City . Plug Research . Immigrant . ~scape )

DJ, producer, and Pallete Recordings label owner John Tejada is
without question one of the most respected and prolific techno
producers to ever come out of the U.S..  With dozens of singles,
remixes, and full length albums to his credit, his abundant output is
made only more impressive by the consistently high quality of his
musical creations.

Tejada's worldwide in-demand status lands him in SF quite often to
drop his trademark DJ sets of refined, musical techno.  But it is a
rare treat indeed to get to witness him perform all his own material
live, with all gear and no laptops, as he will this month.  Prepare
for a very special evening with a true icon of modern dance music.


plus special guest:

ELI BINGHAM  ( Gourmet . Nightlight . Movim )


and [KONTROL] residents:

NIKOLA BAYTALA   ( Robsoul . Junior Boys Own . S.W.A.T. )
SAMMY D  ( Classic . Buzzin' Fly . Dirtybird )
CRAIG KUNA   ( Concept SF . ESDJCO )
ALLAND BYALLO   ( Leibe*Detail . Floppy Funk )


________________________________________________

The ENDUP
401 6th St @ Harrison, SF
10pm - 6am / 21+ / $15
http://www.theendup.com

FREE until 11pm!

Full bios, pics and FREE music:
http://www.kontrolsf.com

[KONTROL] on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/kontrolsf

http://www.westaddradio.com/kontrol/

http://www.kontrolsf.com/K27/K27F.jpg
Flyer back:

Poster:

GIF animation:
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K27/K27G.gif

____________________________________________________

JOHN TEJADA

Normally associated with his peers in Techno from Detroit, Europe and
elsewhere in the US and the world, John Tejada has embraced electronic music
as a personal frontier, expanding on his formidable resume as a Techno
recording artist as producer and remixer, DJ, and label owner. With dozens
of singles, remixes, some film and TV work and contributions to sample CDs
to his credit, this recent expansion has born a slew of tracks deeply
informed by his uncompromised aesthetic honed over years of diligent
production which finds its roots in Detroit Techno but references a far
broader range of music, both in and outside of electronic music. His
musically formative years were steep in Classical music, growing up in
family of performing artists--his mother a soprano singer and his father a
conductor which then widened to include hip hop, DJing and finally,
electronic music.

Known for crafting a brand of subtle, musical techno, his recorded output
ranges across tempo and genre lines, from chilled out affairs with spacious
arrangements to pulsating, densely layered, deeply energetic tracks that
work magnificently in the hands of DJs as well as on the home stereo.
Earlier on, his music found release on labels such as A13, Multiplex and
Generation R&S. Following on to those successes, he established his own
imprint, Palette, in Los Angeles, in 1996, and has enjoyed years of steady
growth and recognition. The label has served as an exclusive outlet for his
own prodigious output but has recently begun to expand its roster. He has
also continued to record for other labels such as Pokerflat, Plug Research,
Seventh City, Playhouse and others, often in collaboration since 1991 with
Arian Leviste, and alongside these numerous singles, has also produced
albums for Playhouse, Palette, Plug Research, deFocus, Moods and Grooves,
Immigrant and A13.


John Tejadas' Website:
http://www.paletterecordings.com/

John Tejada's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/John%20Tejada

John Tejada production sampler:
includes bits of: Sweat (On The Walls), Mono On Mono, Chorgs, Higher, and
The End Of It All
http://www.kontrolsf.com/K27/john_tejada_production_sampler.mp3


________________________________________________


ELI BINGHAM

San Francisco local Eli B made his DJing debut at legendary '90s techno
weekly Static, before taking up a residency at Sabotage under the tutelage
of the One Trak Mind crew and residents such as Sutekh and Kit Clayton.
Eventually promoting a series of his own events called Sex In Zero Gravity,
with guests like John Tejada and Kenny Larkin, Eli turned to production in
2002.  To date, he has had releases on such labels as Gourmet, Movim, Slow
Motion Sequence, MDEX, and Nightlight Music, as well as international gigs
in London and New Zealand.  His DJing style blends classic techno and house
with an eclectic selection of modern electronic dance.


Eli Bingham's Discography:
http://www.discogs.com/artist/Eli%20Bingham

Eli on MySpace:
http://www.myspace.com/eli_b


_____________________________________________________

http://www.kontrolsf.com

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Content-Disposition: inline

Almost. . . The first thing I think of is this charming little tale from the
gay scene in Dallas circa 2001. A friend of my boyfriend at the time was at
home alone late one night and had a compelling desire to shove something up
his ass. So he searched his house high and low, and all he could find was a
zucchini (or a cucumber, one of those elongated green vegetables). So he
takes this zucchini, goes to town with his, has himself a gay old time and.
. . when he's done, he leaves it where he found it without so much as
washing off the shit from his ass that was now surely encrusted on this
zucchini.

So, the next day at dinner time someone in his family passes him the salad
and what's on it but that very same zucchini from the night before. He
skipped the salad that night, but his parents, grandmother, and siblings all
had healthy portions. . .

Since I heard that story the elongated green vegetables have been oh so much
less tempting for me.

Subject: [sfraves] Hilly Kristal, founder of NY punk mecca CBGB, dies 

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C7EA71.1F937530
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Hilly Kristal, founder of NY punk mecca CBGB, dies 

2 hours, 59 minutes ago 

Hilly Kristal, the founder of New York punk rock club CBGB, which helped
make the Ramones, Blondie and Talking Heads stars, has died at age 75, his
daughter said on Wednesday.

Kristal died on Tuesday from complications of lung cancer, his daughter,
Lisa Kristal Burgman, said.

He founded the club in 1973 hoping to showcase country music, calling it
CBGB & OMFUG, for "Country, Bluegrass, Blues and Other Music For Uplifting
Gourmandizers."

But the club drew few country acts and instead became a breeding ground for
punk rock, playing host to the likes of Patti Smith, Television, Living
Colour as well as countless local hopefuls that never made it to the big
time.

"He loved country, but he loved music even more, and as a singer-songwriter
himself, he knew rock musicians needed a place to play their own music," his
daughter said.

Marky Ramone of the Ramones said in a statement, "Hilly was an integral part
of the punk scene from 1974 until his death."

"He was always supportive of the genre," he said. "In an era when disco was
the mainstream, Hilly took a chance and gambled. The gamble paid off for
both him and for us. We are all grateful to him and will miss him."

Johnny Rzeznik of the Goo Goo Dolls, who first played CBGB in the late
1980s, said agents from recording companies often came to the club. "So many
bands would have never have made records unless they came to CBGB," he said.

Kristal was born in Manhattan but his father moved the family to Hightstown,
New Jersey, soon after. He became a concert violinist by the age of 9. In
the late 1950s, Kristal sang in the men's chorus at Radio City Music Hall.

He went on to manage Manhattan jazz haunt the Village Vanguard, booking acts
like trumpet player Miles Davis. He opened a bar that served sandwiches,
such as the Hilly burger, that later became CBGB.

Kristal lost a battle last year to stop CBGB from being evicted. Its last
shows in October featured Patti Smith and Blondie's Debbie Harry. The club's
clothing store, CBGB Fashions, remains open a few blocks from the original
club.

"He wanted the club to survive him," his daughter said. "He is survived by
the fans and bands that played there."

 

 

 

 

 
<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/RaversForPeace/post?postID=vD9Mdq8-lqq1AtiTmI
s2Bhtc_S6DJZz5MIZKXan73ArH4BSVpyE5FXlhjatBSAZjpoe8OBzMlGP__vPf>

"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is nothing
but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look and look
and look at all those X's..."

"And?"

"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."

-Kurt Vonnegut


"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Playlist linked off my myspace page:
myspace.com/hsomusic

Throwin down breaks, right now.

I'm going until Noon Pacific.

I'll be on again tonight from 6-9PM Pacific.

-- 
Holt Sorenson
hso@hsomusic.com
hsomusic.com
myspace.com/hsomusic

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] the burned man coverage

Here's the note from Paul Addis explaining the stint, as if it needs explaining:


Hi, folks. This is the *alleged* arsonist/douchebag/attention whore
himself, writing you from Fernley, NV, where I have been chilling out
for a couple of days.

Having read your various comments, a few things should be addressed.
First, this operation was extensively planned well in advance, and the
number one thing to Black Rock Intelligence was that NO ONE be hurt.
If you people actually knew us, you'd know that we have an extensive
background in doing things exactly like this. In fact, we were on the
ground for some thirty minutes before ascent, scoping the scene and
clearing people in order to minimize any possiblity of injury to
others. We were aided by several people who were recruited on the
playa the night of this burn (BRI has no idea who they are, so don't
bother asking).

Second, the operation was planned in conjunction with the lunar
eclipse because Black Rock Intelligence knew that another event at the
trash fence would draw the bulk of lunatics to it, rather than to the
Man. In fact, one of our peripheral operatives aided in getting as
many people to the fence event as possible to help BRI achieve its
goal of zero injuries.

Third, word went out across the playa days in advance that Black Rock
Intelligence was pulling this op. This word continued to go out right
up to the moment that our chief operator began the arduous climb up
the guide wire. As you can all see from the results, BRI performed
flawlessly in this regard.

We could give a fuck less what you all think of us for doing this.
Most of you are newbies who have been drawn in by the semi-religious
nature of the event, or maybe just the easy drugs and easier sex. You
have nothing to offer the event other than your fucking money and
obedience. You spend the rest of your lives in mortal fear of
everything that insurance companies tell you to fear, and pretend that
you're free and clear because you spend four days at a desert
bacchanal where spinelessness is not only encouraged but genetically
replicated for implementation in successive generations. In short, you
are the swine of which Thompson spoke. Get over yourselves.

Some of us live quite well without fear. Doing so requires the
ultimate in what Burning Man used to represent: personal
responsibility and individual liberty. That's all been lost in the
last decade of Burning Man's history. Consider this operation a
history lesson that was desperately needed.

One final note: Black Rock Intelligence has been permanently
disbanded. All other operatives have made the ultimate sacrifice by
swallowing their L-pills to avoid being captured alive. I am the sole
surviving member of BRI and ask that you respect my mourning period
for those who gave their lives so that this operation was a complete
success.

Paul D. Addis
Fernley, NV


On 8/30/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

Subject: [sfraves] the burned man coverage and Hippy Capitalists

That message was so DEAD ON. The only thing I would
add is a definition of what the writer does not
address exactly.... 

It's a phrase I made up when the dead heads lost their
parking lot and shows and started ruining the rave
scene. 

HIPPY CAPITALISM

DEFINED AS: Capitalists using hippy idealism for the
purpose of seperating the idealists from their money
via a mock-display of those same ideals. The HC
usually takes on the appearance of the group they are
extorting. The HC knows the lingo, mind-set, and
culture of the sub-group they are targetting, and to
many, appear to be a bullwark of the cause. Many HC's
have narcicistic tendancies, and fancy the idea that
they are leader of the group, a revered contributor,
and in many cases, also think of themselves as
artistic leaders.

Thats it.

E

>Date: Thu, 30 Aug 2007 14:07:11 -0700 (PDT)

>That message was so DEAD ON. The only thing I would
>add is a definition of what the writer does not
>address exactly....
>
>It's a phrase I made up when the dead heads lost their
>parking lot and shows and started ruining the rave
>scene.
>
>HIPPY CAPITALISM
>
>DEFINED AS: Capitalists using hippy idealism for the
>purpose of seperating the idealists from their money
>via a mock-display of those same ideals. The HC
>usually takes on the appearance of the group they are
>extorting. The HC knows the lingo, mind-set, and
>culture of the sub-group they are targetting, and to
>many, appear to be a bullwark of the cause. Many HC's
>have narcicistic tendancies, and fancy the idea that
>they are leader of the group, a revered contributor,
>and in many cases, also think of themselves as
>artistic leaders.
>
>Thats it.
>
>E
>
> >
> > Having read your various comments, a few things
> > should be addressed.
> > First, this operation was extensively planned well
> > in advance, and the
> > number one thing to Black Rock Intelligence was that
> > NO ONE be hurt.
> > If you people actually knew us, you'd know that we
> > have an extensive
> > background in doing things exactly like this. In
> > fact, we were on the
> > ground for some thirty minutes before ascent,
> > scoping the scene and
> > clearing people in order to minimize any possiblity
> > of injury to
> > others. We were aided by several people who were
> > recruited on the
> > playa the night of this burn (BRI has no idea who
> > they are, so don't
> > bother asking).
> >
> > Second, the operation was planned in conjunction
> > with the lunar
> > eclipse because Black Rock Intelligence knew that
> > another event at the
> > trash fence would draw the bulk of lunatics to it,
> > rather than to the
> > Man. In fact, one of our peripheral operatives aided
> > in getting as
> > many people to the fence event as possible to help
> > BRI achieve its
> > goal of zero injuries.
> >
> > Third, word went out across the playa days in
> > advance that Black Rock
> > Intelligence was pulling this op. This word
> > continued to go out right
> > up to the moment that our chief operator began the
> > arduous climb up
> > the guide wire. As you can all see from the results,
> > BRI performed
> > flawlessly in this regard.
> >
> > We could give a fuck less what you all think of us
> > for doing this.
> > Most of you are newbies who have been drawn in by
> > the semi-religious
> > nature of the event, or maybe just the easy drugs
> > and easier sex. You
> > have nothing to offer the event other than your
> > fucking money and
> > obedience. You spend the rest of your lives in
> > mortal fear of
> > everything that insurance companies tell you to
> > fear, and pretend that
> > you're free and clear because you spend four days at
> > a desert
> > bacchanal where spinelessness is not only encouraged
> > but genetically
> > replicated for implementation in successive
> > generations. In short, you
> > are the swine of which Thompson spoke. Get over
> > yourselves.
> >
> > Some of us live quite well without fear. Doing so
> > requires the
> > ultimate in what Burning Man used to represent:
> > personal
> > responsibility and individual liberty. That's all
> > been lost in the
> > last decade of Burning Man's history. Consider this
> > operation a
> > history lesson that was desperately needed.
> >
> > One final note: Black Rock Intelligence has been
> > permanently
> > disbanded. All other operatives have made the
> > ultimate sacrifice by
> > swallowing their L-pills to avoid being captured
> > alive. I am the sole
> > surviving member of BRI and ask that you respect my
> > mourning period
> > for those who gave their lives so that this
> > operation was a complete
> > success.
> >
> > Paul D. Addis
> > Fernley, NV
> >
> >
> > On 8/30/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com
> > <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > > Some great discussion of the early burning of the
> > man etc. at laughing squid.  Some quasi-intelligent
> > comments too, so read the whole thing if you are
> > interested in art and counterculture.
> > >
> > >
> >
>http://laughingsquid.com/burning-man-set-on-fire-early-arson-is-to-blame
> > >
> > > I also enjoyed this blog article:
> > >
> >
>http://www.10zenmonkeys.com/2007/08/28/burning-the-man-with-hunter-s-thompson/
> > >
> > >

non-attendees' buttons so much?

I think it has something to do with a hugely wasteful party being thrown in
the middle of the desert by people who love to claim that they're
environmentally friendly. My main gripe is that it seems to be populated
mostly with a particularly virulent mixture of hippie and yuppie that is fa=
r
more obnoxious than just a plain hippie or a plain yuppie.

Also, the STDs.
